The petition of economic viability and the the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that: (i) the financial situation of students enrolled at Australian post secondary institutions is already extremely difficult (as indicated in the Commonwealth Department of Education's 1979 survey of student incomes and expenditure) and any substantial increase in the financial commitments of students would gravely worsen their financial difficulties. (ii) The imposition of tuition fees for second degrees and post graduate degrees will deter many able persons from enrolling-such courses and further preserve higher education for the rich. (iii) The introduction of a loans scheme, subsequent review of the level of TEAS and the tightening of the eligibility criteria for TEAS will cause great financial hardship and will deter students from enrolling in tertiary institutions. Your petitioners therefore pray that: 1. post-secondary tuition fees not be reintroduced for any courses or for any category of students. 2. the visa charges upon private overseas students be removed immediately. 3. the Government reverse its decision to introduce a loans scheme and instead increase and extend TEAS scheme. The humble petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth: That Australia, as an affluent and developed nation, should be able to expend more of its resources on the alleviation of human suffering and deprivation in other less developed countries. Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Commonwealth Government will: Increase overseas aid to 0.7 per cent of Australia's GNP. Health Care Services: Queensland To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth: That we strongly condemn any action taken by the Federal Government which will lead to the destruction of the Free Hospital and Medical Services of the State of Queensland. And your petitioners therefore humbly pray: That the Parliament reject the proposed health cost sharing arrangements between the Commonwealth and the State governments and guarantee the maintenance of the present scheme whereby all Queenslanders who wish to a vail themselves of these services may do so. And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray. by Mrs Darling. Petition received. Curfew at Eagle Farm Airport To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth: That noise levels created by aircraft using Eagle Farm Airport already constitute an annoyance and inconvenience to those residents living near the airport and along flight paths. That relaxation of the Eagle Farm Airport curfew to allow any aircraft including TAA's airbus to fly into and out of Eagle Farm Airport between 11 p.m. and 6 a.m. would(a) substantially increase the inconvenience and annoyance caused by aircraft noise because the operation of aircraft at this time would seriously disturb people's sleep; (b) contradict and negate a commendable undertaking made by the Commonwealth Minister for Transport, the Hon. Ralph Hunt, in reply to a question on notice in the Parliament, that the curfew will remain on the runways at the existing site at Eagle Farm Airport. Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Commonwealth Government will not approve the application of TAA-or any other airline-to relax or withdraw the curfew at Eagle Farm Airport. And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray. by Mrs Darling. Petition received. Overseas Aid Tertiary Education To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth: That public investment in tertiary education in the form of Federal Government funding is an investment in Australia's future and enables Australia to meet the demands of technological innovation. That grave concern has been generated as a result of the Government's decisions to: (a) abolish the Education Research and Development Committee; (b) terminate special support for educational research; (c) scale down in-house and contracted research activities of the Department of Education; (d) scale down participation in international education activities, particularly UNESCO and OECD; (e) further tighten already restrictive eligibility guidelines for TEAS; (f) supplement TEAS assistance by means of a loan scheme; (g) phase in tuition fees for students undertaking degrees and diplomas subsequent to an initial tertiary qualification; (h) reduce grants to universities and colleges to take account of fee income; (i) completely abolish 30 colleges of advanced education and (j) scale down various engineering schools in colleges of advanced education around Australia. Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government will rescind these regressive decisions and desist from obvious attempts to pave the way for a complete reintroduction of tertiary fees. And your petitioners as in duty hound will ever pray. by Mrs Darling. , Petition received. Service Pensions To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth: That, as ex-servicemen are eligible (0 receive a service pension five years earlier than other Australian males are eligible to receive an age pension, subject to certain conditions, so too should the age at which the means test is applied to pension increases be reduced for service pensioners by five years to age 65. Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government will, in recognition of the service they have performed for their country, and because of reduced life expectancy as a result of that service, reduce the so-called means test [rce age limit for service pensioners from 70 years to 65. And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray. by Mrs Darling. Petition received. Crown Property: Municipal Rates To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth: That the concentration of Commonwealth and State property in the City of Fremantle constitutes a burden on ratepayers to a degree not experienced by most municipalities in Australia. That the non-payment of general rates by the Commonwealth and State Government imposes a 39 per cent higher rate in the dollar on Fremantle ratepayers. That the 1980/81 Western Australian Grants Commission allocation to Fremantle of $460,000 does not adequately compensate for a loss of rate revenue $900,000. That we support the efforts correct this inequitable treatment of its citizens and to resolve the contradiction whereby land owned by the Crown does not pay rates but property leased by the Crown includes a rate component. Your petitioners therefore humbly pray: That the Government give immediate effect to Recommendation 14 of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation Report of May 1978 which calls upon ". the Commonwealth Government to recognise explicitly its obligation to compensate municipalities for loss of general rate revenue as a consequence of Commonwealth Government immunity in respect of Crown property" and that Commonwealth statutory Authorities ". be required as a matter of course to follow overall Commonwealth Government policy". And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray. by Mr Dawkins. Petition received. Proposed New Constitution To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth: That we believe that Australia's constitution is undemocratic and should be replaced by a democratic constitution, particularly as regards the new standard for regulation of vitamin and mineral supplements. We believe: 1. This legislation will curb our individual freedom to care for our own health according to need, environment, climate, etc. 2. These substances have proven their efficacy in maintaining health rather than destroying it and should remain freely available. 3. Why curb these suhstances while other noxious and toxic substances are freely available to the obvious thorough detriment of our society-e.g. commercial alcohol and tobacco. This new constitution should be drafted at a representative directly elected people's convention following extensive public debate, and then put to a referendum of the people. The petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Parliament, as a matter of urgency, will help to promote such public debate and will arrange for the holding of such a people's convention and referendum. And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray. by Mr Good luck. Petition received. Your petitioners most humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled should take action as it deems appropriate to ensure the continuing functioning of the Betsy Women's Refuge and the network of shelters in Australia. We ask that the Federal Government acknowledge that 'Betsy' and its counterparts provide housing and care for women and children in violent situations, and the Government agree to meet the financial responsibilities for continued and effective Refuge functioning. The Federal Government should be informed that one in every five applicants are not accommodated at the Betsy Refuge due to overcrowding or full occupancy. We therefore petition for full and adequate funding, and as petitioners for this we humbly pray. by Mr Mountford. Petition received. Toxic Shock Syndrome To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned showeth that your petitioners are gravely concerned by the threats to women's health and lives posed by Toxic Shock Syndrome, and urge the following steps to be taken as a matter of urgency: (1) Tampons, sanitary napkins, vaginal deodorants and similar sanitary products to be re-classified under Therapeutic Agents (not under 'Cosmetics' as at present), in order to bring them under the scrutiny of the Australian Drug Evaluation Committee. We believe manufacture must be under the strictest hygienic conditions. (2) After re-classification, we urge an immediate government-funded inquiry into all aspects of manufacture and content of these products. This must lead to: (i) contents of product and instructions for correct usage to be shown on packaging; (ii) removal of synthetic fibres, chemicals or ingredients that are potentially or actually harmful to users. (3) Allocation of extra funding for ongoing research by the National Health and Medical Research Council into these products, results of this research to be made public to ensure all are fully informed. This campaign of public education would necessitate multilingual formation where appropriate. Your petitioners, therefore, humbly request that Parliament take immediate and positive action to avert possible threats posed to women's health by implementation of the above measures. And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray. by Mr Milton. Petition received. To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. Staging of American B52 Bombers To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned in the Northern Territory respectfully showeth: Trade Unions That the proposed use of Darwin Airport as a refuelling and Rest and Recreation base for American B52 bombers: Jeopardizes the welfare of the citizens of Darwin and of all Australians, in that it establishes a stronger potential of Darwin being a nuclear target in any conflict between the USA. and another power. Impedes the sovereignty of the Australian nation in that Australian citizens would have neither control nor knowledge of whether B52s: (a) Carried nuclear weapons (b) Were engaged in bombing missions against another State. Violates the Australian people's independence and links this nation irreconcilably with United States foreign policies thereby destroying the potential for independent Australian defence policy. Violates democratic procedures in committing the Australian nation to participation in future wars without due consultation and informed assessment by Australian citizens and further increases the militarisation of the Indian Ocean thereby increasing the likelihood of super power conflict in this region. Jeopardizes the welfare noise pollution and the threat of accidental radioactive fallout will increase substantially to the residents. Negates the potential of the Australian nation to establish itself as a nation of Peace in the Pacific region and violates Australia's commitment to the Nuclear NonProliferation Treaty. Your Petitioners therefore pray that the Members of the House of Representatives will ensure that the Prime Minister withdraw the offer of Darwin, or any other location in Australia, as a base or depot for American B52 Bombers. And that furthermore will ensure that any request of such usage by the US. Government be rejected. And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray. by MrKent. Petition received. Speaker: Mr HOLDING
Title: VIETNAM VETERANS
text: I give notice that on the next day of sitting I shall move: That, in view of the continuing problems facing Australian Vietnam veterans, their wives and families allegedly caused by numerous herbicides, pesticides and other chemicals used in the Vietnam war, the rising costs of the Commonwealth Institute of Health epidemiological study and the difficulty of establishing control groups for study, this House calls on the Government to establish immediately an independent judicial inquiry to allow all of the scientific and medical evidence already available to be properly tested. Speaker: Mr MCLEAN
Title: SINAI PEACEKEEPING FORCE
text: Is the Prime Minister aware of reports from Argentina indicating that our Deputy Prime Minister has stated that Australia would not take part in a peacekeeping force in the Sinai? Was such a statement made? Is such a statement a correct assessment of Australia's position on this matter or is the Government's curNotice or Motion rent position the same as that outlined by the Minister for Foreign Affairs in his statement to this House on 26 May?

Speaker: Mr MALCOLM FRASER
Title: SINAI PEACEKEEPING FORCE
text: When I first saw that report this morning I believed that it could not be correct because it did not represent Government policy which, as the honourable gentleman rightly has indicated, was outlined by the Minister for Foreign Affairs in a definitive statement to this Parliament. That statement indicates the serious nature of the question before the Australian Government and the nature of arguments both for and against Australia's participation which have to be weighed with the utmost seriousness before a final decision is made one way or the other. The Press Secretary of my colleague the Minister for Trade and Resources was in touch with him earlier today and I understand that a notice has already been put up in the Press Gallery indicating that the report was incorrect. Speaker: Mr MORRISON
Title: SINAI PEACEKEEPING FORCE
text: My question is directed to the Prime Minister. In view of Israel's reprehensible action in Iraq, will the Prime Minister deny the supply of Australian forces to a non-United Nations force in the Middle East?

Speaker: Mr MALCOLM FRASER
Title: SINAI PEACEKEEPING FORCE
text: I think it is generally realised that what has happened in recent days, or even hours, in the Middle East will only add to tensions. I would have thought that many governments would want to do all they could to reduce tensions. Israel and Egypt have been in pursuit of peace between them. Ten years ago that would have been regarded as an impossible achievement, but it has been advanced by the Camp David Accords. They may not have gone as far as many people would like; nonetheless the situation is a vast improvement on the state of open hostility and warfare that had existed between Israel and Egypt in the past. If things can be done to advance the cause of peace in the Middle East, I believe that any government should weigh the consequences seriously. There should not be a necessary connection between the events of the last day or two and the furtherance of the Camp David Accords. I hope that honourable members of this House will be able to keep the two things separate in their own judgments. NA

Speaker: Mr COLEMAN
Title: POLISH REFUGEES
text: I direct my question to the Minister representing the Acting Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. I refer to my speech in this House on 13 May concerning the refusal of the Polish authorities to permit the immigration to Australia of the wives and children of recent Polish refugees in Australia. Can the Minister inform the House whether any progress has been made in negotiations between the Australian and Polish governments on this matter?

Speaker: Mr WILSON
Title: POLISH REFUGEES
text: The House is well aware of the interest and concern of the honourable member for Wentworth in this matter. The House is also aware that the Government is currently accepting approximately 4,500 East European refugees in this financial year. This is the highest intake of the program which has been running for some years and which has always included a high proportion of Polish refugees. At the time the refugees are interviewed by Australian immigration authorities they are advised to expect considerable difficulties in the achievement of family reunions in the event of their settling in Australia. This is not the making of the Australian Government but rather reflects difficulties that members of the refugee families can expect in being granted exit authorities by the Polish Government. Reports received by the Government early this year suggested that since the events of late 1980 the Polish authorities were becoming more liberal in the issue of passports for travel to Western countries. According to one recent report, the number of travel documents issued so far this year is 45 per cent higher than in the corresponding period last year. However, it now appears that this general liberalisation is not always being extended to the families of people whom the Polish Government regard as being illegally abroad. The Australian Government has received complaints that passport applications are being refused and of attendant difficulties being experienced by family members of Polish refugees. The House can be assured that the Government is concerned about an early and acceptable solution to the problem of family reunions and is conscious of the anxiety of members of the Polish community. We will continue to make representations to the Polish authorities in such cases where these are seen to be helpful and appropriate. NA

Speaker: Mr SCHOLES
Title: SINAI PEACEKEEPING FORCE
text: The Prime Minister will recall that in a cable to General Haig the Minister for Foreign Affairs stated that the area to be covered by the Sinai multilateral military force is beyond the area of direct strategic concern to Australia. In the same cable he also drew attention to the commitment of Australia to providing troops for a United Nations force in Namibia. I ask the Prime Minister: Is it appropriate that Australia should commit its limited military resources to an area which the Government indicates is of limited or no strategic concern to Australia and for a purpose that the Foreign Minister informed General Haig the Government did not consider necessary?

Speaker: Mr MALCOLM FRASER
Title: SINAI PEACEKEEPING FORCE
text: I will not comment on the substance of questions based on communications between my colleague and Secretary of State Haig. I am disturbed at the persistent thrust of questioning by members of the Opposition. Quite plainly the Middle East area has been disturbed by hostilities for decades. We know quite well that a major disturbance or difficulty, a further movement by the Soviet Union from Afghanistan to Iran using what it has gained in Afghanistan as a foothold, would have possibilities of enormous consequence for the whole world. Whilst that area might be beyond Australia's direct strategic area of concern-let me emphasise the word 'direct'-it is quite clear that events could happen in the Middle East which would be of vast consequence to all the Western world, including Australia, and of vast consequence to the peace of the world. It is against that background that I think any Australian government ought to look seriously at the arguments for and the undoubted arguments against any possible Australian involvement. There are legitimate and honourable arguments on both sides of this equation. It comes, finally, therefore, to a matter of judgment by the Australian Government as to what is in the best interests of Australia and of our contribution to peace. We have been involved in other areas beyond our direct strategic interest. We have said that we are prepared to contribute to the United Nations peacekeeping force in Namibia. That is not in our direct area of interest, but it will help the common cause of peace and well-being of peoples if the United Nations proposals for Namibia can be put into effect. That will involve a multination peacekeeping force. On many occasions we have been involved in areas beyond our direct strategic interest because we have a concern for the well-being and peace of mankind. NA

Speaker: Mr DONALD CAMERON
Title: NATIONAL TUNE
text: Mr Speaker, that was a very statesmanlike reply, to the previous question. Does the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment recall that some years ago, at the time of the referendum to choose a national tune, the nation was advised that in due course a suitable form of words would be chosen? Is the Minister aware of my forwarding to his predecessor several word form suggestions received by me from people right across the nation and my asking his predecessor whether we are awaiting a revolution before something is done? Can I inform my constituents that the present words are now official, or has the Government something else positive in mind? If so, when will the long awaited decision be made?

Speaker: Mr WILSON
Title: NATIONAL TUNE
text: Yes, I am aware and other members of this House are well aware that in 1977 a poll was taken to get the view of the Australian people as to which tune they preferred for a national tune. The majority of people at that poll indicated that they wanted the tune known as Advance Australia Fair. Since that time there have been many suggestions as to which words should be used, for there are at present no official words for that tune. In 1979 the Government established the National Australia Day Committee and sought from that Committee its views on the words which might be used for the tune. That Committee considered the traditional words by P. MCCormick. It also sought the advice of the Literature Board of the Australia Council, and a contemporary poet was asked to put forward some suggestions. Many suggestions were received from people around the country. I am aware of the great interest of the honourable member for Fadden and constituents within the electorate of Fadden whose words he has sent to me for consideration. There are continuing representations on the matter. I am aware that there is great interest in a decision as to what words should be adopted, and the matter is under consideration. I am not in a position to indicate when a decision can be reached as to what will be the official words. When that decision is reached one would hope that a conclusion can be achieved resulting in words that will be generally acceptto advance able to the Australian people. NA

Speaker: Mr MILTON
Title: SINAI PEACEKEEPING FORCE
text: My question is directed to the Prime Minister. Is it still the Australian Government's view, as stated in a cable to United States Secretary of State Haig on 27 April, that European Community countries have a major stake in a peaceful settlement in the Middle East? Is it also still the case, as stated in that cable, that the Australian Government is particularly concerned that no major European countries appear to be under active consideration as possible participants in the proposed United States-organised peacekeeping force in the Sinai? In the event that Australia agrees to' join the peacekeeping force, does this reluctance by nations with an established stake in Middle East peace to endorse the American proposal expose an Australian contingent to the charge that it is a mere rump force and part of a United States strategic ground presence in the area? In view of these considerations, and in view of the serious olence in the Middle East arising from the Israeli raid on Iraq, will the Government declare unequivocally that Australia will not take part in the Sinai peacekeeping force and become embroiled in a situation that is becoming increasingly dangerous?

Speaker: Mr MACKELLAR
Title: SINAI PEACEKEEPING FORCE
text: It seems that today the Opposition has a series of prepared questions with which it will continue despite the answers in relation to this matter given by the Prime Minister and by the Minister for Foreign Affairs before he left Australia. Australia's attitude towards the peacekeeping force has been elaborated inside and outside this House. A series of questions has been asked in relation to it. Our attitude is utterly clear and we do not propose to depart from that stated attitude. NA

Speaker: Mr CADMAN
Title: INFRASTRUCTURE PROJECTS
text: Has the Treasurer noted the intention of the Queensland Government to avoid demands on infrastructure borrowing by having private enterprise build a power station complex? Is the decision an example that other States could follow? What would be the effect on the economy of States seeking alternative methods of financing projects rather than borrowing funds themselves?

Speaker: Mr HOWARD
Title: INFRASTRUCTURE PROJECTS
text: I have seen some Press reports this morning of a disposition on the part of the Queensland Government to encourage private enterprise to construct some power stations in that State. Not having seen the fine print of the decision, all r can say at this stage is that, if in fact the Queensland Government in future is going to adopt the practice of encouraging private enterprise to do things that private enterprise is able to do, this Government can only welcome that decision. As honourable gentlemen will know, projects such as power stations, if undertaken by private enterprise, are subject to the test of profit, which is a very important consideration so far as undertakings of this type are concerned. As the honourable gentleman will know, the Commonwealth has invited the States to examine what parts of proposed infrastructure projects could be carried out by private enterprise. We understand that that matter is currently being considered by the States. I can further say in reply to the honourable gentleman only that, if indeed the Queensland Government has decided to place a greater emphasis on encouraging private enterprise to undertake these things, that is to be welcomed, and if in fact it is carried through to action it is an example that could properly be followed by other States. NA

Speaker: Mr DEAN
Title: TOWNSVILLE AIRPORT
text: My question, which is directed to the Minister for Transport, concerns developmental work at Townsville airport. Did the 1980-81 Budget allocation of $5m allow for certain planned work to be undertaken to provide initial facilities for the introduction of international services at Townsville airport? Has the cost of the works escalated to $5.6m and has the additional $600,000 been provided by the Government? Have any of the works been abandoned? Are the works to be completed in about mid-July, as provided for in the main project contract? Is the Government considering financing additional work not originally planned last year? Will the Government go ahead with planning and providing new domestic airport facilities at Townsville?

Speaker: Mr HUNT
Title: TOWNSVILLE AIRPORT
text: I am not sure of the over-run of expenditure at the Townsville airport, if there is any over-run, but I would like to assure the honourable member that none of the works referred to has been abandoned. Construction is proceeding to schedule. Only one or two minor items are expected to be completed beyond the end of July. All the initial works have been completed or will be completed by then, to facilitate the limited number of international flights from and to Townsville at the present time. A number of other works are currently being considered by the Department. One of them is the construction of additional apron for domestic air services. There is provision for a shelter between the international airport and the domestic facilities and additional car park facilities for international traffic. Quite a lot of planning is being done to improve the total facility at that airport. The Government, in the course of its budgetary considerations, will take a decision on the level of expenditure and the level of priority which will be accorded to that expenditure within the overall expenditure for airports throughout Australia. I might say that the Government is facing a very substantial capital outlay in airport expenditure right around Australia. The latest estimates indicate that it could be somewhere between $1,300m and $1,400m over the next decade in order to accommodate the wide-bodied jets and to provide upgraded facilities at some of our major capital city airports. Townsville, now being an international airport, will of course be receiving the priority necessary to maintain a growing degree of traffic from that airport. I would like to thank the honourable member for Herbert, as the local member for that area, for the co-operation that he has given me in relation to plans that have been developed. NA

Speaker: Mr RUDDOCK
Title: DRUGS TASK FORCE
text: Can the Minister for Administrative Services advise the House of the progress and achievements of the Federal-New South Wales police task force established in 1979 by the Commonwealth and New South Wales governments following the recommendations of of Rethe Williams and Woodward royal commissions drugs? In particular, can he give details of the incurred in mounting this task force and the Health number of officers involved?

Speaker: Mr NEWMAN
Title: DRUGS TASK FORCE
text: Organised crime, and par'It is ticularly drug trafficking as a part of that crime scene, presents very large probof lems to this Government and to various State governments. Therefore, the Commonwealth in co-operation with State governments, is determined that it will develop its policing agencies, particularly the Australian Federal Police, so that the people involved in organised crime and drug trafficking can be sought out and eventually brought to justice. The formation of the joint task force with the New South Wales Government was a joint initiative following the Woodward and Williams royal commissions. The honourable member asked about the number of people involved. We have 15 Australian Federal Police officers attached to the task force, as well as three administrative officers who are provided by the Department of Administrative Services. I am told that the net cost up to the end of this financial year is estimated at about $380,000. That is after allowance is made for the cost-sharing arrangements between the two governments. The methods that have been used by the task force are those that were recommended by Williams and Woodward. Basically, the task force is targeting its efforts on those people who are central to drug trafficking or drug trafficking groups. Of recent months the Commonwealth directed that the task force extend its activities to looking into drug trafficking associated with the Nugan Hand bank and people involved in drug trafficking who may have had associations with the Nugan Hand bank. The work of the task force will take a long time. I am advised that up to 1 May the task force can claim the following achievements: Five groups involved in the importation of heroin have been broken up. Another four groups supplying heroin have also been broken up, as well as a minor group that has been supplying morphine. In all, a total of 66 offenders have been charged on a total of 186 counts, including 40 persons in relation to the importation and supply of heroin and three in relation to the supply of morphine. Until 21 April this year a total of 718.5 grams of heroin had been seized by the task force. I reiterate that the commitment of the Government, in co-operation with State governments, to attacking those people involved, particularly those central to organised crime, is something that we intend to pursue with all the vigour we can. I have spoken about only one task force. Other task forces have been established or are intended to be established with the New South Wales and Victorian governments. I hope that as the months unfold the sort of success that the New South Wales-Commonwealth task force is having will also be evident in those task forces. NA NA

Speaker: Mr WALLIS
Title: BROADCASTING
text: Is the Minister for Communications aware of commitments made by his predecessor to establish an Australian Broadcasting Commission frequency modulation radio station in the area near Port Pirie to provide an FM radio service to the northern areas of South Australia? Have these plans been either deferred or scrapped as a result of the activities of the razor gang? If so, when is it anticipated that the station will be established to provide this service to this area?

Speaker: Mr SINCLAIR
Title: BROADCASTING
text: As a result of the Broadcasting and Television Act amendment a capacity has been provided to the Government to allocate FM commercial stations throughout regional areas of Australia. It is my intention, once the legislation has passed through Parliament and been proclaimed, to produce a policy proposal, which will be distributed for public information, on the general ambit of the program for extension of FM broadcasting beyond the city areas, where it is now operating on a commercial basis. The next stage certainly will take into account the area to which the honourable gentleman referred. I am aware that there are pockets in that area where significant difficulties are experienced in getting adequate alternative channels on most household radio sets. At the same time, public broadcasting licences are also being issued in a number of areas. There is no impact at all, either on the issue of public broadcasting licences or on commercial FM licences, from anything that was decided in the Review of Commonwealth Functions. Our intention is to proceed with those in due course, and I hope that before too long there can be a reasonable extension to the honourable gentleman's electorate. The Australian Broadcasting Commission FM stations depend on the overall funds to be provided for the ABC. As I indicated in this House yesterday, they are matters that are still to be concluded in discussions between the ABC and the Government and, of course, will be announced in this Parliament in the Budget context. Speaker: Mr YOUNG
Title: PUBLIC FUNDING OF POLITICAL
text: I refer the Prime Minister to his statement that the 'system of public funding of political parties is corrupt'. Is the Prime Minister aware that the system of funding of political parties applies in the United States, Canada, France, Austria, West Germany and Sweden, amongst other countries? If the Prime Minister is aware of these things, does he believe that all these countries have a corrupt electoral system? If he does believe this, will he assure the I-louse that he will not raise these questions when he visits these countries and thus make Australia look mean in the eyes of the other countries?

Speaker: Mr MALCOLM FRASER
Title: PUBLIC FUNDING OF POLITICAL
text: - What I have said, of course, is that the legislation in New South Wales will be corruptive and corrosive, and it is. It means quite plainly that every time Mr Wran cannot build a pre-school and cannot do something for a school or hospital he is ing of the Australian Labor Party with taxpayers' dollars is more important than that pre-school, that women's refuge and all the rest. If that is Mr Wran's and the Labor Party's exhibition of political priorities, quite plainly it is not ours. In addition to that, the Wran socialist legislation establishes an inspectorate which will make it possible for the New South Wales Government to discriminate against individuals and corporations that provide funds to other political parties. It also make it possible for the New South Wales socialist Government to give that information to trade unions, which would then use their undoubted power to destroy the corporations that might be involved. The purposes of this legislation are certainly of very doubtful merit. They will be corruptive of the political processes in New South Wales. They represent a condemnation of the political priorities of the Wran Government. The most insidious part of the legislation is the establishment of the inspectorate, which will be able to look into the books of political parties, with the resulting invasion of privacy involved and then the possible use of the information that will be thus gained.

Speaker: Mr MCVEIGH
Title: THE HOUSING INDUSTRY
text: For the information of honourable members, I present the Indicative Planning Council for the Housing Industry report 1981. I seek leave to make a statement. Leave granted.

Speaker: Mr MCVEIGH
Title: THE HOUSING INDUSTRY
text: -The Indicative Planning Council is an independent and authoritative advisory body which forecasts short, medium and long term trends in the housing industry. Membership of the Council is drawn from builders' and industry organisations, orgllnisations in the housing finance sector, trade unions, the real estate industry, materials suppliers, the Reserve Bank of Australia, Commonwealth departments and individuals prominent in the housing industry. Council Chairman, Professor Noel Drane, is Professor of Economics at Macquarie University, Sydney. Besides the national Council, committees operate COUNCIL in each State and the Australian Capital Territory. It is impressive to see the way that members of the industry with such varied backgrounds have worked hard together to produce such a timely and relevant report. Sectional interests have been set aside so that an impartial overview of industry prospects could be compiled. I thank Council members, and particularly the Chairman, for their work. The report concludes that due to the impact of the resources boom, higher overseas migration and the emerging widely-based recovery in the economy, demand for housing will show a gradual increase over the coming three years. Further growth in demand is likely during the 1980s. The report also predicts that housing activity will increase not only this financial year but also in 1981-82. Dwelling completions are forecast to increase from 129,300 in 1979-80 to 135,500 in 1980-81 and to 139,000 in 1981-82. Dwelling commencements, after showing strong growth in 1979-80, will increase to 136,000 in 1980-81 and 139,000 in 1981-82. Such forecasts, which are good news for the housing industry, are given added weight by the calibre and composition of the CounciL But the Council also notes that this relatively strong picture for activity is dependent on housing finance institutions being able to compete for funds at interest rates which do not choke off demand. The council also recognises that the national picture hides wide variations at the State and regionallevel. In 1981-82 activity is expected to increase markedly in Victoria, Western Australia, the Australian Capital Territory and the Northern Territory, remain buoyant in Queensland, show some recovery in South Australia, remain stable in Tasmania and decline marginally in New South Wales. The capital investment surge, particularly in resource related projects, is identified as a major influence on housing activity during the 1980s. It will bring significant benefits to the ing industry but also may create problems. The main message contained in the report is that the health of the housing industry will depend upon sound policies and planning by all levels of government, designed to ensure that the industry is a beneficiary not a casualty of the resources boom. The resources boom is already placing large demands on the capital market. The industry is facing competition from semi-government authorities borrowing to finance resource related projects and infrastructure development. The Commonwealth Government has sought to restrain its own demands on the capital market by reducing overall public sector borrowing and by reining in the deficit. But the Commonwealth Government cannot expect to be able to overcome all the problems on its own. We will lead the way but planning, co-operative effort and far sighted policies are required from all levels of government. State Governments should examine their expenditure plans critically to ensure they do not siphon off too large a share of available finance and labour. They should plan adequately for the housing and social facilities they need before they permit massive development. If all governments do not discipline their own demands and those of their authorities, housing borrowers could be crowded out and the building industry dealt a damaging blow. I hope this is borne in mind by States when they come to the Loan Council discussions on 19 June. At the same time State Governments should be aware that unrealistic interest rate ceilings imposed on permanent building societies are hindering the flow of funds to these institutions. Neither the permanent building societies nor any other financial institutions are guaranteed a share of available funds. If interest rates are overcontrolled, the report points out that the result is frequently to dry up the flow of funds. That is why the Commonwealth allowed an increase in bank housing loan rates and removed the regulations on deposit rates. Bank lending for housing has picked up considerably. In the March quarter 1981, the number of loans approved for dwellings by savings banks increased by over 9 per cent in seasonally adjusted terms. That means more prospective home buyers are now home owners. But it does not end just with the finance sector. The resources boom is likely to place pressure on the labour market and housing costs. Already the Commonwealth Government has taken initiatives designed to ensure that the benefits of the resources boom are maximised and that people's housing aspirations are met. Besides announcing hous- higher immigration targets, which increase the supply of labour to all industries and also increase housing demand, the Government has lifted its support for labour training programs. The Commonwealth has supported the work of the Commonwealth-State Ministerial Council on housing costs. It supports the conclusion of the inquiry into the nature and terms of employment in the New South Wales housing industry that there should be no change to the cost effective subcontract system of housing construction. As the Council has indicated, in a climate of intense competition for finance and pressure on housing costs, further pressures are likely on home ownership rates. I will be watching the situation closely and examining the flexibility of housing programs and appropriateness of policies. The housing industry is well placed to capitalise on the growth forecast by the Council during the 1980s as long as constructive and far sighted policies are maintained. I can assure honourable members that my Government has a strong commitment to maintaining a healthy and stable housing industry and that this report will be carefully considered as we make our major decisions. The 1981 report of the Indicative Planning Council has come at an opportune time and provides a full discussion of the prospects and issues facing the industry. I highly recommend it to members of this Parliament, the industry and governments at all levels. I present the following paper: Indicative Planning Council for the Housing IndustryMinisterial Statement, 10 June 1981. Motion (by Mr Sinclair) proposed: That the House take note of the papers.

Speaker: Mr UREN
Title: THE HOUSING INDUSTRY
text: The Opposition welcomes the report of the Indicative Planning Council for the Housing Industry. The Council is a remnant of what is remaining of the Federal Labor Government of 197275. This Council was established by the Labor Government to advise on the estimated needs and capacity of the housing industry in order to assist government intervention to provide stability in the housing market. The sad situation is that in no way has this market forces government paid any heed to the advice of the Indicative Planning Council in the past. But we are grateful for the crumbs that faJl from the Government's table. At least this body is still intact and can still make reports to this Parliament. Someone in the bureaucracy may draw information from it and that may have some influence on the Government. The advice from this Council remaiIis the only advice which is provided to the Federal Government in relation to housing policy. I am not trying to be personal about the Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr MCVeigh) or the Government-I suppose, in a way the Minister will want to take advice from the Council-but we know that the market forces controlled by the Department of the Treasury are the dominant authority in the Government relating to the housing industry. They are the forces that really determine what occurs in relation to the housing policy of this Government. The housing industry has been the real casualty of this Government's policies both in the public sector and in the private sector. This is the only body which can have any influence on the Federal Government's housing policy. The recommendations of the Henderson Commission of Inquiry into Poverty have had no real influence on the housing industry policies of this Government. The Government also has not been influenced by the recommendations of the Eyers Committee of Inquiry into Housing Costs. The Government has failed to assess the housing needs, the number of homeless in Australia, the population mix, size and age, the regional dislocation that is now occurring on a large scale, the quality of housing stock, and the adequacy of aged persons accommodation. The Fraser Government shows no evidence of acting on the advice of the Indicative Planning Council. It shows no intention of intervening to offset the disruptions in the housing market and no preparedness to plan ahead. The Indicative Planning Council considers the effective demand for housing rather than housing need. I criticise the membership of the Indicative Planning Council even though, as the Minister said, it does represent a very wide section of the community. It has representatives from the building associations such as the Master Builders Association and the Housing Industry Associationthe ownership and production level of the industry. It includes one representative of the trade union movement on its membership, but there is no representative of the consumers on that Council. There is no representative from the housing co-operative groups and other bodies such as the Shelter organisation that should be represented so that there is some understanding of the socia.! needs and problems. This Council underestimates the real requirements for housing provision. It underestimates the real social problems of 80,000 families which are on housing commission lists. These lists are growing and will grow dramatically in the next few years. It underestimates the problems of the 250,000 people living in caravans and in temporary accommodation and it underestimates the problems of the 150,000 homeless people throughout this country. Australia's population in the next two decades will increase by one-third. There is no indication of that in the report. The Indicative Planning Council works from the assumptions of government policy in relation to impacts of resource development and the availability and price of housing finance. Yet in no way does this Indicative Planning Council report deal with the deregulation of the capital market or interest rate increases. There is no real understanding of that situation. Jn fact, the Council implies that interest rates will hold their present levels. In spite of all these limitations, the Indicative Planning Council report poses a challenge to the Fraser Government's policy. The 1981 report indicates a range of pressures emerging in the supply of labour, land and material in the context of expanding resource development or tourist resort activity in a number of regions. It is a matter of regret that the earlier years when such advice was available were not used more effectively to absorb labour lost from the building industry and to train a higher number of new apprentices. When labour and materials were under-used, this Government began cutting back on the housing industry in a way which raised prices. The price of building materials in New South Wales, where the housing industry was more buoyant, rose at a faster rate than in States such as Victoria. The Government undermined the capacity of the housing industry to cope with emerging needs. As a result, the pressures are greater now than they should be. According to the Council, the resources development activity is likely to affect the demand for housing in ditIerent regions, the cost of housing, the availability and cost of housing finance, finance for developers and infrastructure finance. On page 7 of its report the Council states: Whether this demand is reflected in the rental sector or as increased demand for owner occupation, will depend in part on the availability and cost of housing finance, and in the cost of purchasing a dwelling. The Council implies that the position is so difficult that more housing will be made available for rental. I question that. The monthly repayments for a $30,000 loan, repaid over 25 years at an interest rate of 11.5 per cent, are $305. I ask leave of the House to incorporate in Hansard a tabk setting out monthly repayments and total repayments of loans of $20,000, $25,000 and $30,000 with various interest rates over a 25-year period. Speaker: Mr HOWARD
Title: INSURANCE BROKERS
text: by leave-I wish to outline for the information of honourable members the conclusions reached by the Government following an assessment of the recommendations in the report of the Law Reform Commission on insurance agents and brokers. The Law Reform Commission report recommended that legislation should be introduced to regulate the activities of insurance brokers by imposing registration requirements, compliance with certain financial requirements, compulsory professional indemnity and fidelity guarantee insurance, and prohibitions on certain relationships between brokers and insurers. Views were sought on the Commission's report from insurance industry organisations and other interested parties, the States and the Northern Territory. Whilst those groups that responded generally favoured regulation of brokers, their reaction to the terms and coverage of regulation proposed by the Commission differed significantly. As should now be well known, the Government's general view on intervention in commercial relationships is that a clear need must be demonstrated before Commonwealth regulatory legislation is considered. The Government does not believe such a need has been established either by the Law Reform Commission or by others to fall. making submissions. Indeed, the recent decision on the Review of Commonwealth Functions requires by the Government critical examination of existing supervision of the insurance industry. It is clear that over the past decade the vast majority of broker transactions have been conducted in a satisfactory manner. Losses from broker insolvencies over this period, while attracting considerable publicity, have represented only a minute proportion of business turnover. The more than $7.25m known to the Law Reform Commission to have been lost from broker insolvencies in the 10 years preceding its report represented less than 0.1 per cent of premiums handled by brokers in the period. Furthermore, it appears that much the greater part of those losses have affected businesses rather than individual consumers. It should also be recognised that the States have traditionally been the regulators of intermediaries such as solicitors and estate agents and in areas of consumer protection. Several States either have or are foreshadowing legislation in this area. One aspect of the pattern of operations of insurance brokers does appear to be worthy of special attention. That is the traditional practice in the general insurance industry whereby brokers,'and to some extent other insurance intermediaries, are entrusted with premiums and other moneys which they are able to hold and invest, or otherwise use on their own account and receive income therefrom, over and above whatever commission is received by them. While it is evident that the great majority of brokers handle these moneys in a responsible manner, potential does exist for abuse. In large part, this practice amounts to extended credit to brokers. It enables them to extend credit to clients or to hold permium moneys for periods exceeding normal business practice before the moneys are transmitted to insurers. In regard to this particular aspect, consideration will be given, in consultation with the insurance industry, to amending the Insurance Act 1973 with a view to circumscribing dependence on extended credit terms and to ameliorating the consequences of broker failure for insureds and insurers, provided this can be done without undue regulation or administrative cost. I will be making a further statement on that matter, in conjunction with the introduction of a number of amendments to other areas of the Insurance Act, at a later date. I should emphasise that the Government remains of the view that the most effective approach to the basic issues relating to insurance brokers is the velopment of sound and appropriate selfregulatory practices. No system of regulation can provide an ultimate assurance against loss in all circumstances. But with self-regulation consumers are given the freedom of choice to deal with intermediaries who are subject to such arrangements, or, if they prefer, to seek services elsewhere in the market. The ultimate judgment can therefore rest with the consumer. I might point out that there is now no shortage of readily identifi.able insurance brokers operating within the marls@twho are subject to selfregulatory arrang<;ment-. Specifically, the Confederation of Insurance Brokers of Australia and the Insurance Brokers Association of Australia impose membership requirements similar in a number of respects to the controls recommended by the Law Reform Commission. The Government would hope that any prospective legislation by the States will recognise the benefits of these existing self-regulatory arrangements and have regard to the advantages associated with uniformity in controls. In this latter context the Commonwealth Government stands ready to assist wherever it may be able in achieving uniformity between the States in this area. lam conscious that there will be, some in the community who will be disappointed that the Government has not embarked upon the course of full-scale regulatory legislation. However, Governments have to justify the cost of regulatory intervention by establishing a clear public interest in so intervening. It is often erroneously claimed that the only answer to default and dishonesty is to pass more legislation. On the contrary, whilst legislation can go some way to reduce bad and inefficient practices, no amount of legislation can provide a guarantee against fraud and business failures. The attempt to provide such a guarantee would inevitably bring with it an unacceptable level of intervention in the affairs of businesses and individuals. I commend the statement to the House. I present the following paper: Regulation of Insurance Brokers-Ministerial Statement, 10 June 1981. Motion (by Mr Killen) proposed: That the House take note of the paper.

Speaker: Mr JACOBI
Title: INSURANCE BROKERS
text: The statement by the Treasurer (Mr Howard) destroys five years of detailed and constructive investigation and recommendations on the need to legislate for insurance brokers. It is a slap in the face to the industry, to the community and, above all, to Professor David St Leger Kelly and the staff of the Law Reform Commission. The Treasurer has not de- even had the courtesy to pay a tribute to the work of the Commission. The track record of Liberal governments over the years, particularly in the field of insurance, is simple of definition. It is a series of rearguard actions taken after the horse has boited, of closing off certain stable doors in the hope that in doing so policy holders will be protected against further failures in the future. This is no way to act responsibly in a highly complex and important industry such as the insurance industry. I have read the debates in England; the Minister obviously has not. Past actions have been repeated time after time. Voluntary controls, however good, have been inadequate. There are some who would argue that the industry itself has failed and has passed the buck to the Government. It has been demonstrated that the whole field of insurance is too big and complex to be operated entirely by voluntary control. The policy holder pays a premium and in return he gets a mere promise-a promise that on the happening of some event the insurer has a contingent liability and will pay. The Government must be concerned as to whether the people who make the promise are suitable persons. It must also be concerned about their capacity to carry out their promise. The purpose of the legislation was to deal with the severe problems faced by members of the insuring public in relation to misconduct by insurance intermediaries. There are thousands of insurance intermediaries in Australia, the vast majority of whom act honestly in the interests of c1ients. But cases of misconduct occur and, when they do, severe loss can be caused to numerous honest people. The Treasurer has a distinct lack of enthusiasm for the controls suggested by the Commission after an exhaustive inquiry. Yet the Commission's central recommendations have the support of the insurance industry in its entirety. There has been a whole succession of collapses of insurance broking houses. The total estimated loss incurred in the period 1969-1981 is not $7.3m but $14m. Losses of $7m have occurred over the last two years. Someone has to pick up the tab. Obviously this is left to the policy holders. The Government's inaction in relation to the question quite frankly is scandalous. Protective legislation is desperately needed by the community and will be welcomed by all reputable sections of the industry.1t is utterly irresponsible to unload that sponsibility back on the States. All the Government is doing is recycling the need as in the case of uniform company law. The need for regulation has been long recognised overseas, within the State jurisdictions and by all sections of the community involved in the broking industry. As the Minister is aware, the Queensland Insurance Act 1960-1976 provides for the licensing of insurance brokers. The United Kingdom brought in legislation in 1977. The Whitlam Government drafted legislation before we got turfed out in 1975. Since then there have been a number of somersaults by the Government. In April 1976 the then Minister Assisting the Treasurer announced that the Government would introduce legislation for the supervision of insurance brokers. In March 1977 the Government reversed this decision and announced its intention to pursue a scheme for self-regulation in conjunction with the Insurance Brokers Council. In 1979 the Treasurer announced that he would seek government approval to develop legislation for voluntary regulation arrangements for brokers. Six months later he changed his mind again. The Government refused to grasp the nettle, claiming that there was no consensus among the various bodies representing brokers on the forms of control that ought to be and might be introduced. The Treasurer waited until the Law Reform Commission's report was tabled. One might be forgiven for expecting that the tabling of the Commission's report would finally have stimulated the Treasurer into some action. Great was my disbelief when on the tabling of the Commission's report in September of last year, after four years of extensive consultation, the Treasurer announced that as a first step in the Government's consideration of the present report he proposed to seek the views of the industry, organisations and interested parties. The report's recommendations, which I will deal with in more detail, show clearly and unequivocally how endemic is this Government's capacity for vacillation on the regulation of business in the public interest. The Government cannot claim in its defence that the insurance broking lobby is against the legislation. It cannot sustain that claim. Bodies representing the insurance brokers and all sections of the insurance industry have persistently supported and demanded the legislation. We have the spectacle of the Western Australian Government being obliged to bring in legislation. The New South Wales Minister has repeatedly indicated that if the Commonwealth fails to act New South Wales will legislate. The Victorian Minister is committed to bringing in r.elegislation. Unquestionably the only two remaining States will be obliged to bring in legislation to protect the consumer section of the industry. What is the Minister going to have? I will tell him what he will have. He will have a plethora of mismatched, ineffective, inefficient State laws. The situation is scandalous. In September 1976 a reference which I obtained from the then Attorney-General required the Law Reform Commission to report on insurance contract law. I must confess that the Treasurery has overlooked this aspect, which is inextricably mixed up in the whole insurance industry. If one is to bring in recommendations on insurance contract law one has to cover intermediaries. If one does not regulate that one is wasting one's time regulating to update insurance contract law. The Commission reported separately on the regulation of brokers and it is about to bring in a report on insurance contract law. If the Minister were honest, he would request the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) to ask the Law Reform Commission to cancel any further procedures. . It is an appalling situation that anyone may call hImself a broker, whether he is a true broker or an agent tied to a single company. The company is readily misled by this practice, and the major problem with agents is that some insurers will not accept responsibility for them. They choose their agent, but when something goes wrong it is the insured who worries. The insurer simply denies any liability. In the past this has led to scandalous cisions. The insurers have made the insured sign a statement to the effect that the insurer's agent is not the insurer's agent at all. Instead, he is the agent for the insured, and regrettably the courts have upheld this charade. Insurers have also been able to avoid liability by denying that their agents had authority to do certain things. We all know that agents and employees often fill in proposal forms for clients. When those agents make a mistake, the insurer should accept the responsibility. The most frequent complaint is in relation to motor vehicle insurance. A car salesman is an agent or a sub-agent for insurance. He offers to range insurance for the buyer, often at scandalously high ra,tes. He fills in the form on the strength of the answers given to him by the buyer. The buyer tells him that he has had two accidents in the last five years. I have handled many such cases. The salesman knows that the insurer may not be willing to insure a buyer with that record so he writes 'no' alongside the question concerninthe buyer's claims history. In that way he makes sure of the contract and his commission. If the insured makes a claim, the inaccuracy of the answer as recorded by the agent is discovered. The insurer denies liability on the basis of the insured's misrepresentation. When the insured says 'It was your agent who made the mistake', the invariable answer that he gets is: 'Too bad'. The insured loses out. That position is intolerable. Disreputable insurers are encouraged by the law to have concern, but they have no concern whatsoever for the behaviour and ethics of their agents. That is bad business practice. Insurers owe a duty to train and supervise their agents. They will do so uniformly only when they are made legally responsible for their conduct. I suggest to the Minister and to Government members that the real question involved is not so much the question of the need to regulate brokers as the need to get some updated revision of insurance contract law. Perhaps one other disastrous feature of the collapse of the insurance broker, to which the Minister has made no reference at all, is that a policy holder who has in good faith forwarded his premium to the broker may find that due to the broker's failure to forward the premium to the company he is entirely uninsured. Similarly, an insured may have forwarded funds to the broker in settlement of a claim against it, and this sum may not have been transferred to the insurer. It is true tha- insurance companies have persistently, for a varIety. of r-asons, assumed liability. According to the legIslatIon, that payment of a premium to a broker discharges the insured's liability to the inde- surer in respect of that premium. Conversely, that payment to the broker by an insurer of money intended for the insured does not discharge the insurer's responsibility to the insured in respect of those funds; nor should it. Self-regulation has been proved a failure time after time. What is needed is urgent legislation. If there is no legislation, all that we are doing is what we did in the field of company law. We give an open misere to the spiv, the charlatan and the corporate crook. The Minister is misleading the Parliament when he says that the cost involved in ar- self-regulation would be an impost on the taxpayer. If we look at the proposals put by the two insurance brokerage organisations in Australia, it would not have cost a cent. One of their recommendations was that the whole system could be funded entirely from registration fees if the English practice were to be followed. The'Minister was not prepared even to legislate in that form. I repeat that, quite apart from insurance contract law, in the field of insurance brokerage law there is a critical and urgent need for the legislation to be implemented. There is a need for a statutory system of registration of insurance brokers to be supervised by an insurance commissioner, and a life insurance commissioner. There is an obligation for registered brokers to keep all premium moneys and moneys received from insurers in a separate trust account, the investment of which is to be closely controlled. There ought to be heavy penalties for misleading conduct by brokers and agents. Greater protection is needed for consumers by making insurers statutorily liable for the actions of their agents and responsible for premiums received by brokers. The Government's actions, after five years of exhaustive examination, are utterly scandalous and irresponsible. Protective legislation is needed by the community, and it is needed by all reputable sections of the insurance industry. I utterly condemn this Government for its failure to give the insurance industry and the public the protection they deserve. I can say only that after the next Federal election the Labor Government will as a matter of urgency bring in uniform legislation to cover insurance brokers and to update, revise and implement a new code of insurance contract law. Debate (on motion by Mr Bradfield) adjourned. NA NA
