Title: CHRISTMAS ISLAND AGREEMENT
text: Is it the wish of the House to have a general debate covering both measures? There being no objection, I will allow that course to be followed.

Speaker: Mr HURFORD
Title: CHRISTMAS ISLAND AGREEMENT
text: The Bounty (Printed Fabrics) Bill and the Bounty (Textile Yarns) Bill provide for substantial payments of subsidies for the textile yarns and printed fabrics industries. Because they are so important and because so much of the revenue of this nation is appropriated in this way I believe, in spite of the late hour, I am obliged to give the matter full attention and to make a speech that would be made even if the Parliament were not in its dying hours. As we do not intend to divide the House on the Bills I hope that any honourable member who has to catch a plane will do so in the heavy knowledge that I will not be bringing down the Government on this measure. The total full year cost of the assistance will be about $73.5m. The Opposition supports these Bills because they are consistent with our approach to industry policy which recognises, in contrast we believe to the Government approach, the mutual roles of government and the pri va te sector-the necessary partnership. The Bills will result in lower prices for textile products in Australia. The level of assistance granted is very high-indeed, these bounty payments are the highest of any industry enjoying such payments-but the effective rate of assistance provided appears to represent some overall reduction from the previous levels of protection afforded by tariffs and import quotas. As such, we of the Labor Opposition see these provisions as representing an appropriate commitment to Third Reading change in the textile industry and in Australia's economic structure generally at the same time as recognising the necessity for government action to avoid unnecessarily disruptive increases in import competition. But while these Bills are consistent with the Labor philosophy they frankly and ironically point to the sheer inconsistency of the 1981 Liberal-National Country Party Government's Second Reading attitude to matters such as this. The present Government parties went into the election last year making various promises for increased government programs, extolling the virtues of economic policies-the ones they had been applying-and saying nothing about the irrational cutbacks, the decisions to increase taxes or the rhetoric about small government that we have heard since. Government party members approached the people in, I believe, a cowardly way because they were not, as I said, consistent. They misrepresented their own position as well as that of my party. Now we 'hear nothing but talk of cutbacks in the Government sector, small government and leaving it to the private sector. But here the cowardice of the election year is replaced by the different policies of the post-election year. This is not a government committed to cutting the public sector. What it really is doing is effecting a redistribution within the community. A revolution of the rich is going on around us while the Government is pleased to delay programs of assistance for disabled people, while it is happy to reduce the quality and raise the cost of health care, while it seeks to cut government commitment to welfare housing and education. It nevertheless actively pursues measures to increase assistance to business and industry. There is the inconsistency. As I said, Labor supports these Bills, and it supports the provision of reasonable assistance to industry. We are consistent in this attitude because we believe those other areas which I mentioned ought also to receive assistance. I repeat that we are consistent in this attitude because we believe in a co-operative approach between business and government. Just as we accept government responsibility for the welfare of' Australians we accept the vital government role in industry. At the same time we are committed to planning and, where necessary, regulation in the private sector to achieve those objectives which are the basis of those plans. That is the quid pro quo. The current Government provides all of the assistance but none of the vitally needed planning or the regulation to achieve objectives. I am reminded again of the famous phrase of the former honourable member for Fremantle who said that members among the conservative parties are very keen on socialising the losses but capitalising the gains. Of course, there are some exceptions. Parliament heard this morning from the Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr MCVeigh) about the Indicative Planning Council for the Housing Industry. That Council provides an example of what is needed. How inconsistent it is, however, that the Minister in his statement should say: Planning, ao-operative effort and far-sighted policies are required from all levels of government. Yet, at the same time, he is one who supports the nonsense of the small government rhetoric. We should not let the fact that this is the jester from among the Government Ministers disguise the inconsistency of remarks like that and the malice of the Government's neglect to welfare housing needs. So it is with this Government's approach to industry. The fact is that the Government's policies have been a complete failure. Production in manufacturing industry today is no higher than it was six years ago, in spite of such a large increase in population which should have been responsible for an enormous increase in production by now. The risk of inflation is just as great as ever and for that reason the Government's only response is to cut back as soon as there is any evidence of recovery. That is what is happening in the Australian economy right now. The confidence being instilled by expanding Government spending is being stalled in its tracks right now with high interest rates and squeezes on the monetary system. Hesitancy and recession are again evident in the manufacturing sector. The Government's approach is fundamentally wrong. Australia and Australians will not benefit from setting the public and private sectors apart. It must be recognised that each has a joint role to play, one which involves co-operation and coordination. Only on this basis can non-inflationary growth and an increased commitment to the underprivileged be achieved. r assert that only if the Labor Party's approach is adopted to government, to industry and to social development can Australia fully utilise its vast natural advantages. Our attitude to these Bills reflects our consistent approach. We are concerned that the 6,000 to 7,000 workers involved in these industries can maintain their jobs. We want to ensure that Australia retains employment in manufacturing because we know that at the very most the resource based development will generate directly and indirectly only about one-third of the jobs needed to employ our growing work force. At the same time this Bill is a rare one from this Government in that it results in lower prices and provides a prospect for further decreases in prices as a result of increased efficiency. It achieves this by reducing an indirect tax in the tariff previously struck for these goods. The Government rarely looks at its own full scope and responsibility for reducing inflation. Indeed, at least one-quarter of Australia's inflation is directly attributable to the actions of the Government. Most of the rest results from a failure to pursue a responsible prices and incomes policy in the context of economic growth. Instead the Government uses a restrictive monetary policy and public sector penny pinching. The result is that there is no attitude of conciliation in our community and there is no increase in the productive capacity of our industries. Whenever there are signs of growth the inevitable result under this Government's conservative approach is increased inflation. It takes an international energy crisis to achieve any sign of recovery. Most sectors of the economy face continued recession. It was the textile industry'S good fortune that the decisions on its future were made in the months leading up to an election. This Government committed itself to uncharacteristic measures at the time. The Bills that we are debating now are part ofthose measures and part of the seven-year program for the textile and clothing industries. Indeed, although these Bills do not cover footwear, problems in the footwear industry were looked at at the same time. The Bounty (Printed Fabrics) Bill provides for the payment of bounties to the producers of lightweight woven printed fabrics used in making up garments. Existing quotas and tariffs protecting the industry will be removed from 1 January 1982, the date of commencement of the bounty period. The existing assistance arrangements provide an effective rate of protection of 150 per cent to the industry. The bounty is to be paid at a rate of 70 per cent of value added based on factory cost. This is an apparently narrower basis for bounty calculation that than used by the lAC but it is one we support. It is not known how many employees are affected by the Bill, but the total is probably less than 200 persons. The numbers employed have sharply fallen in recent years and will probably fall further as a result of the Bill. Imports currently supply about half of the market. Nine companies manufacture printed fabrics, all of whom are located in capital cities. They include the Beech, Colortex, Australian Textile Printing, Vida Turner and Frenchprint companies in Melbourne; UTA in Hobart, Actil in Adelaide and the Tennyson and Hescham companies in Sydney. The cost of the scheme is about $2.5m per annum-the provisions of the next Bill will cost much more-which is probably a greater subsidy per worker than the wages paid to those workers. As I have indicated, the Opposition supports this Bill. The Bounty (Textile Yarns) Bill also implements part of the Government's seven year scheme for the textiles, clothing and footwear industries, which scheme was announced last year. The Bill provides for the payment of bounties for the production of most yarns which are used in the production of fabrics. The rate of bounty payable will range from 33 per cent to 59 per cent on the basis of value added based on factory cost. Again, this is a narrower base than that used by the lAC, and hence it is difficult to assess the likely implications of these measures. The rate of assistance appears to be lower than initially suggested but higher than ultimately recommended levels. It is lower than that which applies at this time. Bounty on cotton yarns is to be increased from the current 33 per cent to 43 per cent, following industry claims that the rate initially determined would result in disruption. It is impossible t6 tell whether the rate of bounty will be adequate, and we urge the Government to adopt a wait and see attitude; in other words, to monitor very closely the effect of this Bill. The Government should be willing to review rates at a later stage if they are inadequate to maintain employment at reasonable levels. The level of employment in the yarns industry is not known with precision, but is in the order of 6,000 persons. The Fibremakers and Bradmill companies are major producers. Some of their operations are in regional areas which have no alternative employment opportunities offering. At least 35 companies make yarns in Australia and not all of them are in regional areas. But, all of them give employment in particular to migrant workers and others who would not have other job opportunities. The impact of the provisions of the Bill, since they relate to the removal of tariffs and quotas for the industry, are likely to be negative, although no estimate of the loss of employment is available. It should be noted that rapid productivity improvement is occurring in the industry and on this basis 22 per cent of the work force will be lost over the next five years. I only hope that we will shortly have a change of attitude on the part of the present conservatives who rule us and that we will have a more expansionary economic policy in the context of an incomes policy so that we do not go ricocheting back into inflation. I hope this occurs, in particular in the context of this speech so that alternative job opportunities are created at a greater rate. That is badly needed when we see that, even in industries such as the textile, clothing and footwear industries, in spite of the large amount of funds made available in legislation such as this that employment is actually dropping. The full year cost of the scheme iIi the second Bill to which I have referred is estimated at $71m, which implies a subsidy of over $10,000 per worker. In spite of that there will be a drop in employment in these industries. We badly need new job opportunities created in new industries and that will be done only if we have an expansionary economic policy. Once again, I state that the Opposition supports these two Bills. Question resolved in the affirmative. Bill read a second time. Message from the Administrator recommending appropriation announced. Third Reading Leave granted for third reading to be moved forthwith. Bill (on motion by Mr Moore) read a third time. text: I move: Clause 2, page 2, line 28, after "tex" insert", but does not include monofil(c) at least one cross-sectional dimension of which exceeds 1 millimetre; or (d) that is 6.6 tex or coarser". Title: BROADCASTING AND TELEVISION
text: It is not altogether easy in a Bill such as this one to keep track of each of the cross references. In this instance, we omitted some. I apologise to the House for that omission. Third Reading Mr HURFORD (Adelaide) (4.58)-The Labor Opposition believes that the Broadcasting and Television Amendment Bill is a silly and objectionable one. We have made our views on it quite plain during its passage in this place and also in the Senate. Of course, we do not oppose these amendments. They do not make the Bill any more objectionable than it was. They merely signify in what haste the Bill was introduced to this place and how poor has been the administration of it. I repeat that the Opposition does not oppose these amendments. Amendments agreed to. Resolution reported; report adopted. NA Nos. I and 2 (1981) , constituting

Speaker: Mr HURFORD
Title: DISCHARGE OF ORDERS OF THE DAY
text: This motion gives me' an opportunity to say a few words about the Notice Paper and the mismanagement of the House in recent months. Organisationally, I think the session has been the worse in recent years. In fact we would have to go back to 197 J to find a year when the mismanagement was such. The reforms of Mr Fred Daly have been dissipated. It is no wonder that there is agitation for changed working hours which is, of course, manifested in the various ballot papers doing the rounds of the Parliament at present. Some of the sins of the mismanagement relate to facilities, the hours we work, the want of a proper committee system to scrutinise legislation properly, the absurdity of so many of the Standing Orders and the fact that the Standing Orders Committee has not met in spite of all the mouthing and rhetoric that there has been about the need to improve the workings of this Parliament and to achieve more respect in the community for it than has applied in recent years. Furthermore, there are so many cases in which the Opposition has been given inadequate notice of what is coming before this House. The last example occurred just half an hour ago when an amendment was proposed to the Lands Acquisition (Northern Territory Pastoral Leases) Bill. It was not until the amendment was moved in this chamber that the Opposition heard about it. The pacing of the legislation has also been appalling. I refer to the lack of opportunity to debate some of the important issues in the nation. For instance, I place on record that neither of the two business Ministers in whose work 1I have a particular interest as shadow Minister for Industry and Commerce-I refer to the Minister for Industry and Commerce (Sir Phillip Lynch) and the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs (Mr Moore )-has made a ministerial statement during this session about the state of industry and business. From November to April two pieces of major legislation were debated. In May, three pieces of major legislation were debated. In the 10 days of June, by any definition, at least 10 pieces of major legislation have been debated. That means that the average has increased from one piece of major legislation every six weeks of the parliamentary session to one piece each day. On at least three occasions the Government has introduced measures late at night. I refer to a ministerial statement on interest rates made by the Treasurer (Mr Howard) at 10.55 p.m. on 2 December 1980 and the Airlines Agreement Bill and related Bills introduced at 10.53 p.m. on 28 May 1981 by the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon). Also, the Petroleum Products Pricing Bill, bound up with the abolition of the Prices Justification Tribunal, was debated in the dead of night and was given a mere 52 minutes of the program. I could say a lot more but I will not do so because I believe that I have said enough to show just how inadequate the management of this House has been. To conclude, it is worth remembering that the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) in his 13 page election speech with its 47 pages of attachments, made scores of promises. None of those gave a hint of the sort of major legislation to be dealt with in the dying days of this session. Instead of implementing his mandate, we have government by exhaustion. The Prime Minister has put enormous effort into looking after his own friends around the place, his mates-risking internal party problems to deliver on his deals with his backers. That has been characteristic of so much of the legislation that has come before the House, such as the Broadcasting and Television Amendment Bill which was brought back into this chamber in the last few moments. The Government, instead of implementing its mandate, has brought in legislation to help its friends. There have been delays in the legislative program because of the dissent and turmoil within the Government. That should not have been responsible for inadequate time and inadequate scrutiny being given to these major measures. I draw to the attention of the House, as we are discharging a number of items from the Notice Paper, one that stands in the name of the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden). It is Notice No. 13. It has stayed on the Notice Paper since 25 November 1980. It reads: To move-That a Joint Committee of the Parliament be established to inquire into and report on(1) the power, jurisdiction and effectiveness of the Australian Parliament; (2) the privileges of the Australian Parliament; (3) the proceedings and usage of the Australian Parliament; (4) the machinery of the Australian Parliament, and (5) the relationship of the media of mass communications to the Australian Parliament. It is high time that we debated that matter in the hope of setting up such a committee so that we can improve conditions in this place and improve the scrutiny of legislation. This place might then be managed differently; there might be a reversion to the better management that applied after Mr Fred Daly brought in his reforms from 1972 to 1975.

Speaker: Mr BOURCHIER
Title: DISCHARGE OF ORDERS OF THE DAY
text: I wish to make a few remarks following the remarks made by the honourable member for Adelaide (Mr Hurford). First of all, one should point out that the amendments to the Lands Acquisition (Northern Territory Pastoral Leases) Bill were circulated at 2.15 p.m. today. It is not the Government's responsibility to make sure that the shadow Minister is in the House when amendments are made available; it is his responsibility to be here when he knows that the legislation is on the Daily Program. I have some figures before me which relate to the criticisms made about the lack of work carried out by this Parliament. I will have them incorporated at the end of my speech. The figures compare the allocation of time for parliamentary debates in the Fifteenth Parliament, from 1937 to 1940, and the current Parliament, the Thirty-First Parliament. In that table three items come to notice. The amount of time allowed for debate on Bills in the Fifteenth Parliament was 66 per cent and the amount of time allowed for debate in the Thirty-First Parliament was 46 per cent. I do not think that is altogether a bad thing. Ten per cent of time was allowed for other major policy debates in the Fifteenth Parliament and 13 per cent of the time was allowed for other major policy debates in the Thirty-First Parliament. The Opposition ought to be delighted about the fact that these figures show that this Government is prepared to give the Opposition ample time to talk. The amount of time allowed for debate of other parliamentary business in the Fifteenth Parliament was 26 per cent and the amount of time allowed for the debate of other parliamentary business in the Thirty-First Parliament was 41 per cent. 'Other business' includes debates on matters of public importance, the adjournment, Grievance Day, general business and debates on parliamentary committee business and questions. So I think that the Leader of the House (Mr Sinclair) and the Government are to be congratulated rather than criticised. They are trying to make the Parliament accessible for debate, not only on Bills, but also more particularly on some of the matters that are raised by the Opposition. About 90 per cent of matters of public importance raised in this place are formulated and initiated by the Opposition. I do not criticise that; it is proper. So the Opposition has had ample time to introduce matters of concern to it. The honourable member for Adelaide mentioned a former honourable member, Fred Daly. I point out that at this time of the year the Labor Party, when in office, was able to get Bills through Parliament not because of the magnificent organisation of Mr Fred Daly but simply because he had absolutely no respect for Parliament. He introduced the guillotine at every opportunity. His record of guillotining Bills through this Parliament is one that I hope that this Parliament and this Government would certainly not want to emulate. We have not introduced the guillotine; we did not need to. For all the complaining by the honourable member for Adelaide, all legislation went through this House with the co-operation of the Opposition. J remember sitting here when Fred Daly was Leader of the House. We sat here very late at night. When an Opposition, whichever party it is, decides to consider a Bill clause by clause in the Committee stages the government of the day has no choice but to sit until that legislation is passed or introduce the guillotine. If Fred Daly was caught at a late hour putting a Bill through the House clause by clause we would inevitably sit late. Otherwise he would have no hesitation in ruthlessly introducing the guillotine which stifled proper debate in this Parliament. Over the term of this Parliament and of the previous Parliament we have introduced the opportunity for honourable members to meet in committees so that more opportunity is given to them to investigate Bills, to report to the Parliament and to debate them. I think that the honourable member for Adelaide is being just a little bit happy that the end of the session is here and he is going away throwing one over his shoulder in having a dig at the Government when, in truth, he knows that this has been a well run and well organised Parliament, as it will be in the next session. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard'the table which shows the allocation of parliamentary time for certain debates. Leave granted. Speaker: Mr SINCLAIR
Title: SPECIAL ADJOURNMENT
text: I move: That the House, at its August 1981, at 2.15 p.m., unless otherwise called together by Mr Speaker, or, in the event of Mr Speaker being unavailable, by the Chairman of Committees. This motion gives me an opportunity to mention a number of those who have made a significant contribution to the Parliament, some of whom will not be with us when the House resumes. There are, of course, in the other place, a number of retiring senators from all parties, some of whom have been here for many years. Indeed, Senator O'Byrne, the father of the Parliament, has been here, I understand, from a time - ot long after the end of World War II. There IS no doubt that within his memory are a great number of changes that have taken place within the Parliament and recollections of personalities that have been associated in it. On behalf of the Government parties I extend our best wishes to him and to all of those from all parties who will at the end of June be finishing their Senate term. There are a number of people within this House who also will not be with us when we resume for the Budget session. In particular I mention John Fox who has been the Parliamentary Liaison Officer for the last two years. Mr Fox came to the position from the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet. He served his term here with due attendance to his responsibilities to both sides of the House. I commend him to his new appointment back within the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet and wish him well in his future career. To Jeff Townsend, who is succeeding him, I extend a welcome on behalf of all honourable members and trust that his association with the Parliament will be as happy and as fruitful as the associations of his predecessors. There are many who serve us silently within the Parliament. There are many whom we recognise yet, perhaps, rarely commend for the contribution that they make. I think it is worthwhile specifically referring to the Hansard reporters, the attendants and the police and all of those who, in their several ways, within the Joint House Department, make the functioning of this place possible. Among those who are predominant in serving the Parliament are the Clerks, who serve us within this chamber and who provide the assistance that enables us to avoid all the human frailties that occur from loss of memory of the Standing Orders or other procedural motions which otherwise might make it more difficult for the procedures of the Parliament to be effectively processed. Finally to you, Mr SPEAKER - and to all honourable memberson behalf of the Government parties I wish a safe journeying wherever you might be during the recess. I hope that there is rising, adjourn until Tuesday, 18 an interesting confrontation between the two sides of the House when we resume in the Budget session.

Speaker: Mr HURFORD
Title: SPECIAL ADJOURNMENT
text: On behalf of the Opposition I extend my tribute to John Fox, the Parliamentary Liaison Officer. During my period as Manager of Opposition Business in this House I got to know John Fox's work well. I admired the way he carried out his duties. J also express the good wishes of the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, the present Manager of Opposition Business, Mr Lionel Bowen. I hope that we will see John Fox back in the Parliament from time to time. I hope he will get satisfaction from the new work to which he is turning. We extend a welcome to Jeff Townsend. Both the Deputy Leader of the Opposition and I have had a chance to work with Jeff for a couple of weeks now and we know that we will have a fruitful liaison with him in the future. A great number of senators are retiring. There have been other occasions when we have paid tribute to them, but honourable members on this side of the House would like to put on record our feelings of warmth towards them and express the hope that they will all have a very long and happy retirement. I also pay tribute to everyone who works in this place. I am inclined to say that if it were not for Government members this would be an enormously attractive place to which we could come from time to time. Of course, I have my tongue in my cheek. If only the Government members behaved as well in the chamber as they do outside the chamber the whole atmosphere of the place would be enhanced. Nevertheless, having said that, I wish them a happy recess. I note that many of them are travelling overseas. Of course, there will not be nearly the same number from this side of the Parliament travelling overseas. I hope that those who do will have a fruitful time. Speaker: Mrs KELLY
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: The enthusiastic new member for Canberra wishes to speak in this adjournment debate. [t is easy to see that I have not very far to go home. In the closing minutes of this session r would like to make a few points in relation to private enterprise in Canberra. I want to take this opportunity to outline how private enterprise operates in one particular industry in Canberra-the retail industry. It is not a pretty picture. The Canberra retail industry is characterised by one dominant firm, the Lend Lease Corporation Ltd, and its associated companies. This company has a stranglehold on the small traders as it controls every major shopping centre in Canberra except the Belconnen Mall. These shopping centres include the Woden Plaza, Cooleman Court, Manuka Village, Monaro Mall, The Boulevard, as well as other offices and buildings in the Australian Capital Territory. It would also be an interesting exercise to trace the shareholdings of Lend Lease in the major retail chains that are established in Canberra. The major problem with Lend Lease in Canberra is the severe contractual provisions it is able to force on small business people as a result of its monopoly position in the local market. Firstly, in relation to rents, because of its dominance and influence in the industry in Canberra, Lend Lease is able to set extremely high levels of rents. In addition, high turnover rates are also applied. This means that Lend Lease has the right to go through the books of each trader every month to collect its percentage of the turnover-up to 10 per cent in some cases. The effect of this is that the trader's profit margins are constantly under great pressure and, of course, this is ultimately passed on to the co-sumer in higher prices. A further cost inflicted on these small businesses by Lend Lease is a percentage for promotional costs and the operating costs of the shopping centre. These costs are, of course, fully incorporated into rents, not added on afterwards. At various times, traders have attempted to get Lend Lease to account for the amounts given for operating expenses and to tell them why income is not shown in relation to general recoverable expenses, but the traders have never received any satisfactory explanation. For example, in relation to the Woden Plaza, Lend Lease has refused to explain the purpose of its so-called 'sinking fund', the total monies accumulated in this fund, whether the sinking fund is used to offset repairs, Retail Industry the reasons for heavy repairs necessary to a new air conditioning system, and the cost of those repairs, the reason for significant amounts of painting-some of which has been done for the first time--and the heading under which these charges are included. The list goes on and on. The traders must pay whatever Lend Lease demands without any satisfactory accounting of these charges being provided. Of course, Ultimately, it is the consumer again who pays for this in higher prices. A further objectionable provision which Lend Lease enforces is to prevent shopkeepers holding meetings. Lend Lease has written to traders in the past asserting its right to enforce this provision. I hope that no honourable member in this Parliament would wish to defend such a blatantly undemocratic arrangement whereby small business people are prevented from holding a meeting to discuss their business affairs. This year, rents and contracts are being renegotiated for a further three-year period. In most cases, this is an ideal opportunity for the management failures of the past to be reviewed and for reforms to be implemented before a further three years of misery is foisted on Canberra's retail traders. Lend Lease has been able to get away with these unsavoury practices in the past because of its dominant position in this industry in Canberra. The small trader has nowhere else to go. I think it is about time that people in this Parliament took an interest in the monopoly situation that has been established in the Australian Capital Territory. For years I have fought against this in an attempt to get a business leases review board established in Canberra. I hope that, before this Parliament again resumes for the Budget session, the Minister for the Capital Territory (Mr Hodgman) will get together with the small business people and the builders, owners and management associations to get a fairer deal for small traders in the Australian Capital Territory. Question resolved in the affirmative. Speaker: Mr HOWARD
Title: ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS
text: The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: (1) Yes, I am aware that some rural organisations have expressed concern about foreign ownership of rural land. The Government respects such views and through its policy on foreign investment looks very closely at proposed acquisitions of rural land by foreign interests. Before any approval is given, other than in c.ases where the purchasers are Australian citizens resident abroad or genuinely intending immigrants, the parties must demonstrate that Australians have been given adequate prior opportunity to purchase the land if they wished to do so and that there will be benefits through development of the property or otherwise to Australia from the investment. (2) The Foreign Investment Review Board keeps records of the proposals submitted for approval under the Govermnent's foreign investment policy. These records do not, however, indicate whether the purchases take place. Similarly the Board's statistics do not record sales by foreign interests to Australians as these proposals do not require notification. I am forwarding to the honourable member a paper on foreign investment in rural land which outlines in some detail the Government's policy and provides detailed statistics. (3) Acqnisitions of rural properties by foreign interests generally involve acquisitions of assets of Australian businesses and, as such, these transactions fall within the scope of the Foreign Takeovers Act. Proposals notified in accordance with the Act are examined by the Foreign Investment Review Board to determine whether they would lead to benefits through, for example, development, marketing and employ-ment opportunities, and to ensure that Australians have been given an opportunity to purchase the land. arrangement, which expires at the The Government considers each proposal carefuliy on the advice of the Board and grants approval only where it is and education opportunisatisfied that the acquisition of land by the foreign person would not be contrary to the national interest. costs associated with their tenI am informed that the approaches adopted by the other countries mentioned by the honourable member are: New Zealand Under the Land Settlement Promotion and Land Acquisition Act 1952, as amended, foreign interests are restricted from acquiring rural land, offshore islands and any land required for public use. The legislation aims to restrict absentee foreign ownership of certain types of land in New Zealand. Restriction of foreign ownership applies to any land of two hectares (five acres) or over in area which is zoned for rural purposes, or is so zoned that farming of any kind is a predominant or conditional use in that zone. However, acquisition of land by a foreign interest may be permitted if: Interests the acquisition is for experimental and research purposes which would benefit New Zealand; or (Question No. (46) intended uses of the land, other than for agriculture, clearly show significant benefits to New Zealand and thus are in the national interest; or an individual alien permanently resident in New Zealand farms the land exclusively for his own use and benefit and has the ability and means to achieve these purposes. If land is part of the assets of a business, and where the consideration involved exceeds $NZ100,000, a non-resident has to notify full details to the Overseas Investment Commission of any proposal that would lead to the non-resident interests controlling 25 per cent or more of the voting rights of the business. Each proposal is considered by the Commission on its merits. Canada The Provinces have primary jurisdiction with respect to real estate and regulations ince. Some of them have fairly restrictive statutes. The regulation of foreign ownership of real estate may also fall within Federal Government responsibilities which are administered by the Foreign Investment Review Agency. Foreign acquisitions of real estate are subject to review to the extent that they represent the acquisition or control of a Canadian business. Sheltered Workshops (Question No. 846) Mr Humphreys asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 24 March 1981: (I) Is he able to say whether Australia is the only English speaking country which has not legislated for conditions in sheltered workshops. (2) In this International Year of Disabled Persons, does he propose to recommend amendments to the Conciliation and Arbitration Act to ensure that persons employed in sheltered workshops gain the benefit of national wage case increases.

Speaker: Mr HUNT
Title: ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS
text: The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable Pensions in Australia member's question: (Question No. 842) (I) The Commonwealth Government has no legislation governing conditions in sheltered workshops. I am, however, aware that some States have legislation which could be used to license, and thereby regulate, sheltered workshops. To the best of my knowledge the situation varies among other English-speaking countries. (2) The Handicapped Persons Assistance Act, the legislation under which the Government subsidies sheltered employment services, does not prescribe working conditions for these facilities. Some control is exercised through requirements that sheltered workshops sign a written agreement when they are approved under the Act. The agreement specifies that approval is conditional upon, inter alia, payment of disabled workers according to the work they perform, and organisations' compliance with relevant State and Local Government requirements on building standards, health and sanitation, safety measures and conditions of employment. In addition to a wage, the majority of disabled people in sheltered workshops receive Sheltered Employment Allowance. This allowance is paid at similar rates to the invalid pension and includes an income test free Incentive Allowance of $5 per week. Sheltered Employment Allowance is subject to the same terms and conditions as the Invalid Pension and undergoes regular adjustment in accordance with CPI movements. This is provided for by section 28A of the Social Services Act, the legislation under which pensions are paid. It is to eligible persons in Australia. noteworthy that Australia's provisions in relation to Sheltered Employment Allowance were commented upon favourably at last year's World Rehabilitation Congress in Winnipeg, as a possible model for other countries. Sheltered workshops also employ a number of able bodied people. The Government, under the provisions of the Handicapped Persons Assistance Act, subsidises the salary of any person employed in a workshop who is directly concerned with supervising or training handicapped people. The indexing of wages for both handicapped and able bodied employees is a matter for decision by the management of each sheltered workshop. stable. Speaker: Mr HOWARD
Title: ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS
text: The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: This matter was thoroughly Review of Post-Arrival Programs and Services for Migrants (the Galbally Report) dated May 1978. The Review group, while recognising that many migrants feel a strong obligation to give financial help to family members in their home country, noted that provisions enabling migrants to send money adequate to meet any family obligations a migrant in Australia may feel. In recording its belief that it was an unreasonable burden on the Australian bates for some of these overseas payments, the Review group noted that it was extremely difficult to check claims as to the existence of the people abroad in respect of whom rebates were claimed, and, more importantly, to take into account their income for the purpose of calculating the rebate. Mr Bungey asked the Minister for Housing and Construction, upon notice, on 9 April 1981: (1) What action has been taken by his Department on the recommendation contained in the 5th Annual Report, for 1979-80, of the Commissioner for Community Relations (page 58) that public housing appropriate to the needs, values and lifestyles of Aboriginal people in all States and the Northern Territory should be provided. (2) In what way would acceptance of this recommendation require changes in the policy or practices of his Department. Mr MeVeigh-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: (1) The 5th Annual Report of the Commissioner for Community Relations acknowledges that Aboriginals are eligible for housing assistance under general welfare housing programs. In this respect, general eligibility criteria apply to Aboriginal people along with any other groups of persons. Aboriginals also receive special assistance by way of earmarked grants under Part III of the Housing Assistance Act 1978, and the Commonwealth-Northern Territory Housing Agreement in recognition of $21.06m and $22. 10m were allocated among the States and the Northern Territory for this purpose in 1979-80 and 1980-81 respectively. Administration of all welfare housing programs funded through the Department of Housing and Construction is the responsibility of the State Governments. The earmarked funds mentioned above are directed to special programs administered by State authorities having special interests in Aboriginal housing including the regional offices of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs. The need to earmark funds to meet the special housing needs of Aboriginals will continue to be recognised in the proposed 1981 Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement. In addition, the Commonwealth Department of Aboriginal Affairs has for many years funded a special program of grants to State Housing Authorities for housing for Aboriginals. In recent years this program has been controlled by the 1978 Aboriginal Housing Agreement. Participation of Aboriginals in policy formulation and management matters is encouraged under this Agreement. Under this program grants totalling $12.9m and $10.7m have been allocated for 1979-80 and 1980-81 respectively. Further, the Aboriginal Housing Association program funded by the Department of iginal communities to establish, plan and administer housing schemes. Funding totalled $20.5m in 1979-80 and is estimated to be $22.lm in 1980-81. Aboriginal Hostels Limited, a company wholly owned by the Commonwealth Government, provides a home environment enabling Aboriginals to avail themselves of education, training and employment opportunities. The Aboriginal Development Commission makes available concessional home purchase loans to eligible Aboriginals who cannot obtain home finance on the open market. (2) Commonwealth grants for Aboriginal housing are directed to special programs for Aboriginals which are either administered by or in liaison with the Commonwealth Department of Aboriginal Affairs and with State Government authorities having well defined responsibilities. These practices are considered to be in accordance with the recommendation of the Commissioner for Community Relations. Mr Hurford asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 7 May 1981: (I) Has his attention been drawn to the studies undertaken by Professor J. W. Nevile of the Centre for Applied Economic Research at the University of New South Wales show that a rise of one percentage point in the nominal rate of interest is enough to reduce investment in fixed capital by about $250m, in terms of April 1981 prices. (2) Is there any substance to Professor Nevile's calculations. (3) If not, what are the reasons. (4) Is this apparent lowering of levels of investment due to high interest rates contrary to the medium and long term viability and efficiency of Australian industry. (5) If so, what steps will interest rates do not produce further increases in the level of unemployment but also that they do not lead to industry being saddled with outdated and uncompetitive plant and capital.

Speaker: Mr HOWARD
Title: ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS
text: The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: (I) to (5) I understand that a paper by Professor Nevile entitled 'Inflation and the Incentive to Invest' refers to the impact that an increase in the nominal interest rate might have on business investment. I also understand, however, that the main point of the paper is to demonstrate the adverse impact that a rise in inflation has effect on interest rates and It is worth noting that simple regression results, such as those cited by Professor Nevile, do not in fact 'show' anything. They can at best provide only a broad guide to underlying economic relationships and cannot capture all the influences bearing on (in this case) private investment. It may also be worth noting that if there is one thing that is abundantly clear about the Australian economy today it is that Australia is not suffering from any shortage of new investment at this time. On the contrary, business investment is likely to grow by around 20 per cent in real terms in 1980-81 and recent expectations data from the ABS point to further very strong growth in 1981-82. Communications in North-western Australia Mr Campbell asked the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 8 April 1981: (1) By what date will the microwave link in the Kimberley region, Western Australia, be operational. (2) Is this microwave link connection with Perth. (3) Is it a fact that even with the installation of the microwave link, the communication system to and within the Kimberleys will remain fragile, vulnerable and antiquated. (4) Will he encourage mediately the installation of a micowave link to Katherine from Kununurra, WA., in order to provide north-west Australia with an alternative communication link to that provided by the north-south microwave link.

Speaker: Mr SINCLAIR
Title: ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS
text: The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: (1) A microwave link between Port Hedland-BroomeDerby is under construction and is planned to be completed by the end of 1982. An extension of this link connecting Derby-Halls Creek-Kununurra is planned to be completed by the end of 1983. (2) The microwave links between Port Hedland-Derby and Derby-Kununurra will connect at Port Hedland to the main co-axial cable system between that town and Perth. (3) The microwave links will be modern and highly dependable. They will employ the latest radio relay equipment duplicated throughout for reliability and powered by solar cells giving independence from ground transported fuel supplies. The antennae and masts will be designed to withstand the cyclonic conditions that occur in the area. The reliability of communications in the Kimberley region will be further enhanced by a microwave link between Perth and Dampier planned for completion in July 1984. (4) The overall advantage in providing a microwave link between Kununurra and Katherine is well recognised. Mr Bungey asked the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 9 April 1981 : Is it the practice of the Australian Telecommunications Commission to ascertain the telephone numbers of addressees of telegrams and to telephone a delivery fee has been paid; if so, what is the purpose of charging the delivery fee. Mr Sinclail'-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: The telegram service offers a personalised message passing service and the fixed component according to the sender's choice of method to be used in passing the message. It is the practice in cases where the sender simply addresses a telegram to a residential or charge rate for Telecom to deliver the message by the fastest means available. Quite often this is by telephone or telex. In these cases, the fee charged is not, therefore, for the physical delivery of the telegram but for transmission of the message by the fastest means possible. Should the addressee require a copy of the message which has been telephoned, it can be provided at no additional charge. Where messenger service would provide the fastest means of delivery or if Telecom judges the messenger delivery would be more appropriate, say for telegrams concerning death, illness, or the like, then this means of delivery is used. The sender, at the time oflodging a telegram, has the option of specifying messenger delivery by including the paid service indicator 'Messenger' before the address, and in such cases physical delivery of the message in these circumstances it may not be practicable to pass the message to the addressee as quickly as when alternative methods such as telephone and telex are used. Mr MACKellar-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: (1) It is presumed that the honourable member is referring (Question No. 2256) in his question to the anabolic effects of oestrogenic substances. The Australian Agricultural Council has requested the National Health and Medical Research Council (NH & MRC) to reconsider its long standing recommendation against the use of oestrogens as growth promotants in meal production. The matter is being considered by the Public Health Advisory Committee of the NH & MRe. (2) Representatives of the industry concerned with drug applications in animal husbandry are interested in the introduction of these agents but it is not correct to say that they are 'pressing' for introduction. Any submissions received from industry concerning such products will be subject to the usual rigorous scrutiny by the appropriate bodies. (3) I am aware of recent press reports in relation to the use of oestrogens as growth promotants in the EEC but I am not aware of any substantial scientific reports indicating that anabolic agents in general are 'out of control' in either North America or the EEe. In that case the Trade Practices Commission stated its intention to take section 50 of the Trade Practices Act to prohibit the takeover, but News Limited withdrew its offer before that action was taken; (3) The present section 50 of the Trade Practices Act is the result of a considered decision taken by the Government when it implemented a substantial Act 1977. (Question No. 1503) Quarantine Procedures and Requirements (Question No. 1713) Mr Bungey asked the Minister for Health. upon notice, on 9 April 1981: (1) Can he say whether Philip the Chimpanzee performed at the Happy Holidays show at the Perth Entertainment in Canberra; if Centre eady in January 1981. (2) If so, did Philip arrive by air from San Francisco, USA., immediately before the show. (3) What quarantine procedures and requirements operated in respect of Philip to ensure that there was no risk to Australian human and animal health. (4) Were normal quarantine procedures or requirements cornpromised or abbreviated in any way in this case; if so, in what ways. . Mr MACKellar-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: (l) Philip the Chimpanzee performed at Perth Entertainment Centre from 5 January to 17 January 1981. (2) This animal and two other chimpanzees arrived in Perth from San Francisco on 3 January 1981 and left Australia on 21 January 1981. (3) The Perth Entertainment Centre was registered as a 'B' Class circus under quarantine legislation for the duration of the animals' stay. text: The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question: (1) Where an appeal is lodged against a decision made by an officer in a Social Security branch office or by a State Director, and that appeal has not previously been considered by a Social Security Appeals Tribunal, the appeal is referred to the Tribunal for registration and is then handled in accord ance with the normal procedures governing social security appeals. These procedures require, among other things, that the decision appealed against be reconsidered by the Department of Social Security and then, if the appeaJis not to be conceded at this stage, dealt with by the Tribunal. Where an appeal has previously been considered by a Tribunal which has recommended dismissal of the appeal, since 9 September 1980 the unsuccessful appellant may appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. The State Director of Social Security in the case of representations made to him from a Federal Member of Parliament, and the Director General of the Department in the case of representations to the Minister for Social Security, could still review the decision appealed against where, for example, additional evidence was supplied, notwithstanding this further right of appeal. The Federal Member is, of course, appeal. Representations from an appeal are dealt with in accordance with usual departmental procedures. (2) Statistics on the average appeals are not collected separately finalised appeals dealt with Tribunals. (3) Statistics on the average time taken in 1980 to process appeals made to the Social Security Appeals Tribunals are not available by pension, benefit or allowance. The average processing time measures the number of working days between the date of registration of the appeal by the Social Security Appeals Tribunal and the date of the Tribunal's recommendation. Speaker: Mr NA BROWN
Title: WORKING DAYS
text: The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: (I) The original 1980-81 partment for Division 286-Administrative and Division 288-Commonwealth Employment Service were those presented to the Parliament in Appropriation Bill (No.1) 1980-81. The Government considered my Department's estimates in the light of its policies in respect of particular areas of expenditure and of general financial The general principles applied to the preparation of estimates by my Department are set out in the Directions issued by the Secretary of the Department of Finance under the Authority of the Audit Act 1901. These Directions are long standing and have been endorsed by successive Governments. The relevant general principles tion 6.3 and provide in essence that: (i) Estimates shall represent a realistic assessment of the sums expected to be spent and shall be based on current or known costs. Items of a recurring nature may be estimated on the basis of experience. (ii) Estimates shall not include amounts in respect of proposals which are so far from firm that it is not possible to form any real estimate be made. (2) The Department of Finance ment of Savings Expected in Annual Appropriations Made By Acts Nos. 141 and 142-Appropriation Acts (Nos. 1 and 2) 1980-81', sets out amounts by which my Department estimated, at the time of preparation of the Appropriation Bills (Nos. 3 and 4) 1980-81, expenditure under the Appropriation Items concerned would at 30 June fall short of the Appropriation originally made. What actual underspending will occur in respect of those or other Items cannot be stated with certainty at this stage. The estimated savings would rellect for the most part the following circumstances: (i) Current expectation that events would not occur by 30 June 1981, in cases been made in the Appropriation Acts (Nos. 1 and 2) 1980-81 in the then expectation that they would occur by that date. (ii) Compliance with Government policy that, as far as practicable, savings be offered as offsets to additional funds sought in the Appropriation Bills (Nos. 3 and4), 1980-81; and (iii) The results of efforts by Departmental management to improve efficiency and thereby reduce costs. Telephone Calls by Staff: Department of Mr Bungery asked the Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 9 April 1981: (1) Has the Minister's attention been drawn to a report in the West Australian of 18 July 1979, page 37, that London metropolitan police reduced its telephone bill by $985,000, or about 20 per cent by use of monitoring device which recorded length, time and destination of telephone calls and the extension from which the call was made. (2) Are personal telephone calls, particularly trunk and STD calls, made by staff of the Department of Veterans' Affairs controlled; if so, in what way. (3) Has any consideration been given to the' introduction of monitoring devices for telephone so, what was the outcome of the consideration. Mr Thomson-The Minister for Veterans' Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question: (1) Yes. (2) Telephones are for official use only, although in an emergency private calls may booked through the switchboard operator following approval by the officer's section head and the costs be remitted immediately to the Collector of Public Monies. It is not permitted to use STD for private calls. Where the switchboard equipment permits, STD access is restricted to those extensions where access efficient operations of the officers concerned. All other extensions are barred from STD and details of trunk calls made from any extension are recorded by the switchboard operator. Where the equipment does not permit STD barring, switchboard operators carry out regular monitoring of calls. (3) Monitoring devices, when available, are installed to record details of calls made and the information received is reviewed by senior staff members. The limited number of monitoring devices available and costs involved prohibit permanent installation on all extensions. The Department of Veterans' Affairs is conscious of the need for economies in telephone usage and regular reviews are carried out in all areas of operations. Staff are made aware of Departmental policies in this regard and are encouraged to restrict telephone usage to essential business matter.' (2) Are personal telephone calls, particularly trunk and STD calls, made by staff of his Department controlled; if so, in what way. (3) Has any consideration been given to the introduction of monitoring devices for telephone calls in his department; if so, what was the outcome of the consideration. Mr M" Veigh-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: Veterans' Affairs (J)Yes. (Question No. 1889) (2) .Telephones in the Department of Housing and Construction are STD barred to the maximum extent possible, consistent with efficiency. Current instructions to staff do not allow access to STD for private calls. An officer making a private call is required to obtain the approval of his supervisor, book a trunk call through the switchboard operator, obtain the cost of the completed call from the operator and pay the Receiver of Public Moneys. (3) Consideration has been given to the use of telephone monitoring devices. Some of the Department's offices have installed monitoring devices and negotiations are continuing with Telecom to extend this control. Motor Vehicle Industry calls in the Department; if (Question No. 1915) Mr Burr asked the Minister for Industry and Commerce, upon notice, on 9 April 1981: (I) What is the annual cost of providing assistance to the Australian motor vehicle industry by (a) direct subsidy, (b) grant, (c) tariff protection , (d) quota protection and (e) other forms of State or Commonwealth assistance. be made. Private trunk calls are (2) Is he able to say how many persons are employed by of such calls are to the motor vehicle industry. (3) What would be the cost of providing an annual pension to all motor vehicle industry employees at a rate equivalent to male average weekly earnings. is considered essential to the Sir Phillip' Lynch-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: (1) (a) to (e) The assistance package for domestic passenger motor vehicle production is made up of a number of interrelated measures. The protective effect of many of these measures, for example, quotas, local content plan, is difficult to quantify in dollar terms. These difficulties are heightened when estimates of the subsidy equivalent of the protective incidence of the assistance package are aggregated and then evaluated on a 'per employee' basis. The latest available estimates of assistance accorded to passenger motor vehicle production are contained in the Industries Assistance Commission's draft report 'Passenger Motor Vehicles and Components-Post 1984 Assistance Arrangements', released on 24 February 1981. Discussion of the effect of the assistance package on consumer prices and the allocation of productive resources is contained in Chapter 6 (especially pp 97-103) of the Commission's report. In appendix 8 of the report, the Commission under which its analysis has proceeded including some of the limitations of its approach. (2) The latest available of Statistics based on the manufacturing census for 1978-79 estimate employment for the motor vehicles and parts industry at 76,664. The Industries Assistance ployment in passenger vehicle production is contained on pp 47-48 of the draft report. From evidence received the Commission estimated that in March 1980 about 65,000 persons were employed in the production of passenger vehicles and components. Of these, approximately 60 per cent were employed by the five Plan manufacturers. The Commission's estimates arc broadly consistent with estimates by the Department of Industry and Commerce which indicate around 69,000 persons are currently employed in the industry-38,500 by the five Plan manufacturers, 400 in assembly outside the Plan and about 30,000 in over 700 establishments engaged in the production of automotive components. These figures cover employment in the manufacturing sector only and do not include as importing distribution and servicing. Estimates provided to the Commission by the Dealer's Association indicated that in 1979 dealers employed about 70,000 persons. Employment by importers is estimated at 12,800 in December 1980. (3) The Australian Bureau of Statistics estimatc of average weekly earnings per employed male unit is $290.00 for the December quarter 1980. On this basis and the lAC and departmental figures provided in (2) above the annual cost of a pension to passenger motor vehicle manufacturing industry employees would be between $980.2m and $1040.5m. (2) Is it a fact that this profit will not be taxable pursuant to section 26AAA of the Income Tax Assessment Act, because the group has sold or is selling a subsidiary company which holds the Elders shares and is not selling the shares recently purchased. Speaker: Mr HOWARD

Speaker: Mr HOWARD
Title: APPLICATIONS FOR PERMANENT
text: The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: (1) The Government remains committed to an amendment of the income tax law as outlined in my statement of 25 September 1980 and in my further statement of 13 October in which I indicated that the amendment would apply from the beginning of the 1977-78 income year. Occupational Safety and Health Mr Hawke asked the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 13 May 1981: (1) Does he regard as appropriate the statements contained in the 1979-80 Annual Report of the Department of Productivity that occupational safety and health is an area of considerable concern to the Department and that the social and economic cost of industrial accidents is known to be massive. (2) Will he outline the reasons underlying the decision of the Committee for the Review of Commonwealth Functions to abolish two national committees operating in the area of occupational safety and health. (3) Does he intend that the policing of such an important area of employee welfare should be left in the hands of employers in the private sector. Mr Thomson-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: (l) The social and economic cost of industrial accidents is know to be massive, and the Government will play its part in Veterans' Affairs efforts to reduce this toll. . (Question No. 2141) (2) The Committee for the Review of Commonwealth Functions was charged with reviewing functions to determine which properly belonged to the Commonwealth and which might more appropriately be handled elsewhere. Its recommendation to scale down activities in the subject area and transfer residual activities to the Department of Industrial Relations was agreed by Government. The Minister for Industrial Relations will be considering how best to handle the work of the two committees that are to be abolished. (3) The responsibility for administering safety and health legislation applying to the workforce rests with the States. The Government will be anxious to co-operate with them in this important area of employee welfare. Mandata System: Department of Foreign Affairs member to the answer provided by (Question No. 2214)

Speaker: Mr HUNT
Title: APPLICATIONS FOR PERMANENT
text: The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question: (1) In reply to Question No. 750 of 10 March 1981 (Hansard, 2 April 1981, page 1339) I said that reviews of pensions payable overseas are generally carried out by mail. (2) The review known as the P.E.R. review is carried out in respect of pensions payable overseas other than those payable through the Geneva office. In lar to the P.E.R. is undertaken. In addition to the scheduled reviews other reviews may be undertaken as and when the need arises. (3) The Department of Social officers overseas and it does not have staff located in every country where pensions and benefits are payable. The review of pensions payable overseas does, therefore, present problems which do not arise in Australia. However, every efrort is taken to ensure that pensioners and beneficiaries living overseas continue to meet the eligibility conditions as laid down in the Social Services Act. Security does not have field Mr Moore - The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: A number of P JT inquiries including those into stevedoring, spare parts, petroleum products and wool broking found that prices charged by the companies, or some of the companies, concerned were higher than justified or that proposed price increases were not wholly justified. Tertiary Tuition Fees In some of those inquiries the PJT determined precisely the (Question No. 2265) justified prices for particular products, but in other cases it indicated the order of price reduction warranted or simply invited companies to review their mark-ups in particular areas of activity. In the case of petroleum products the oil companies at times have been unable to obtain in particular localities, because of market conditions, not only the prices they had proposed to the PJT but the prices found justified by the P1T. Savings to consumers that may have resulted from particular PJT inquiries need to be weighed, against the cost of the PJT's operations, including the direct cost to the Budget, the cost to business in complying with PJTprocedures and the wider effects of price regulation on business investment and the market place. S,ocial Security: Entrepreneurs (Question No. 2340) Dr Klugman asked the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 27 (Question No. 2305) May 1981: (1) Is there a special category of entrepreneurs who gain easier entry into Australia. (2) If so, (a) what are the required'qualifications regarding the financial status of these persons and (b) is it necessary for these persons to have a minimum of $200,000 for investment in Australia. (3) Was he consulted by the (a) Minister for Health, (b) Minister for Social Security or (c) Prime Minister before entrepreneurs were included in the list of disadvantaged persons eligible for free hospital and medical treatment for six months after arrival in Australia. Mr Macphee-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: (I) Provision does exist for the entry of entrepreneurs who will establish and take an active part in running enterprises which will benefit Australia. The benefit may take the form of introducing new technology, improving exports or increasing will be phased in over the employment. Persons who enter under these provisions must satisfy the normal character, health and settlement requirements for migration. Entrepreneurs are exempt from reaching a pass score in the economic factors section of NUMAS, Australia's Numerical Migrant Selection System, as the rules governing the appropriate levels of capital and income required for eligibility are sufficient to guarantee economic viability in Australia. (2) (a) and (b) There are no fixed or minimum financial requirements for entrepreneurs. Entrepreneurs must possess sufficient personal and unencumbered capital to establish the enterprise proposed in their actual amount will depend on the nature and magnitude of the enterprise. (3) The decision to provide medical and hospital cover for migrants for the first six months in Australia was taken following completion of the usual consultative arrangements. Department of Veterans' Affairs: Medical Arrangements (Question No. 2497) Mr Scholes asked the Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 9 June 1981: (1) Is there dissatisfaction within the Victorian section of the Department of Veterans' Affairs, in particular, with the medical arrangements. (2) If so, has the Minister examined the reasons for these complaints which have been detailed by the RSL State Presi(Question No. 2349) dent, Mr Bruce Ruxton. (3) Is there any substance to the complaints: is so, what action has been taken to eliminate the causes for complaint. Mr Thomson-The Minister for Veterans' Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question: (1) I am not aware of any general dissatisfaction within the medical arrangements in the Victorian Branch of my Department. However, there has been criticisms of some individual medical opinions given by Department Medical Officers by the Victorian State Executive of the Returned Services League of Australia. (2) Yes. (3) The criticisms are based on a very few selected cases and any general criticism on this basis appear to be unwarranted. Is the Minister aware that that cemetery contains the remains of several Australian servicemen? Will the Minister give consideration to an Australian Arlington? Will the Minister cause a costing to be done to ascertain how much money would be needed to transfer home the remains of all of Australia's sons and daughters in war cemeteries overseas? In the interim, will the Minister protest to the Maltese Government about this possible desecration? The Minister for Veterans' Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question: I am aware of the recent tese Government wants to bulldoze the graves of Commonwealth war dead in Malta. The reports are incorrect. The Commonwealth War Graves Commission in England, of which Australia and other Commonwealth countries are corporate members, is responsible for the Commonwealth war graves throughout the world, including those in Malta. There are also war graves of nine foreign countries and some 5,000 non-war British burials in the Malta cemeteries. In 1979, the Maltese Government asked the British to remove the remains of the 7,303 buried in the Capuccini, Pembroke and Pieta cemeteries, and concentrate them in the Mtarfa cemetery where there are 1,440 graves. 200 Australian graves are involved. Considerable extra land would need to be provided at Mtarfa I\nd the cost would run into some millions of dollars. Australia and the other Commonwealth countries are opposed to the proposed move of the graves except if it can be shown (and it has not so far been done by the Maltese Government) that there was such an overriding and urgent public need for the land to be used for other essential purposes as to justify disturbance of the graves. Australia has been kept fully informed on the negotiations which have been going on with the Maltese Government since the original request was made in 1979. The Commonwealth War Graves Commission has received many requests from relatives to transfer the remains of war dead to their home country. However, the Commission's policy, which was War and reaffirmed after the Second World War, is that the graves should not be disturbed riding public interest. Agreements have been negotiated with many Foreign Governments on these lines. The Commission is bound to adhere to this policy which was laid down by its Participating Governments, including Australia. A detailed costing of the transfer of the war graves of all Australian veterans back to Australia and the establishment of a National Cemetery for this purpose, would not be practicalor productive in view of the Commonwealth War Graves Commission's policy. There are Australian war graves in over 2,500 cemeteries throughout the World and it is possible that a very large proportion of the relatives of the war dead would strongly object to the disturbance of the remains. All Australian war dead are commemorated in the Australian War Memorial in Canberra. The Australian Government has also established and maintains Gardens of Remembrance in most of the capital cities for the whose deaths were war-related and who are not officially commemorated in civil cemeteries. Mr HowardThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: (1) Data released by the Stock Exchange indicate that as at 29 September 1980 10 of the largest 14 shareholders in Western Mining Corporation Holdings Limited were nominee companies and that these companies held 28.9 per cent of the issued capital of WMC. Stock Exchange data also indicate that as at 5 September 1980 four of the top 10 shareholders in MIM Holdings Limited were nominee companies and that these companies held 11.1 per cent of the issued capital of MIM (excluding that held by ASARCO Incorporated). (2) and (3) In cases where the shareholdings of nominee companies could be of significance ments of foreign investment policy, companies concerned have been asked to ascertain whether the beneficial ownership of the shares they hold in the company is Australian or foreign. Companies have provided such information on request. Section 36 of the Foreign Takeovers Act provides legislative power for information relevant to foreign takeover matters to be sought as necessary but experience to date has been that it has not been necessary to take action in pursuance of that Section. With regard to the provisions of the Companies Bill 1981, Section 261 provides companies with the power to obtain information as to the beneficial ownership of their shares.
