Bankcard Interest Rates Mr Humphreys asked the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs, upon notice, on 25 March 1981: (1) Did he say in answer to my question No. 273 (Hansard, 4 March 1981, page 442) that Bankcard interest rates which. are quoted at 18 per cent per annum, are not compounded daily, and that a true per annum does not occur. (2) If so, what interest would Bankcard charge on a deht of $2,000, if the principal sum at the end of a 12 month period. (3) Would this figure be identical to that which would have been the case if Bankcard had quoted an effective rate of interest on 19.7 per cent per annum. Mr Moore-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: (I) No. In answer to Question No. 273 (Hansard,4March 1981) I stated that I had been advised that Bankcard credit charges are not compounded daily, that is, interest is not charged on interest. (2) The interest charged by Bankcard depends upon whether the debt is generated by a cash advance or a purchase of merchandise. [ am advised that if a debt of $2,000 is generated by a cash advance on 1 January and is not reduced over the ensuing twelve month period the interest charged for that period would be $358.98 which is an effective rate of 17.95 per cent per annum. If the debt is generated by a purchase of merchandise the interest charged would vary between $331.78 and $359.39. depending on the length of the interest free period; this is 16.59 per cent and 17.97 per cent per annum. It should be noted, however. that these examples assume a departure from the condition upon which a Bankcard is issued, that a card holder may make a payment of at least 5 per cent of the amount owing at the end of each settlement period. If this condition were met the amounts of interest quoted above would be reduced accordingly. (3) No. However I am advised that if the interest charged were to be compounded daily, which as [have indicated is not the case, it would produce an effective rate of 19.7 per cent per annum. Such a compounding would result in an annual interest charge of $394 compared with the amounts referred to in the answer to the second part of this question. For the sake of completeness let me stress that I am advised that there is no compounding effect of any kind in the computation of Bankcard interest. After an initial credit charge of 1.5 per cent for extending credit on merchandise purchases (which would normally be applied on the second monthly statement in which the balance outstanding in respect of a particular purchase appears) and for cash advances Bankcard interest is computed on reducing principal at daily rests basis. The total interest component (including the 1.5 per cent credit charge referred to above) included in amounts owing is segregated and disregarded for the purpose of interest calculations. I understand that this differs from many methods of computing interest in Australia. Imported School Work Books (Question No. 873) Mr Holding asked the Minister for Business the recommendations of the and Consumer Affairs, upon notice, on 25 March 1981: (1) Has his attention been drawn to an article headed 'Problems with Photocopying' in the Booksellers Fair advertising Impplement in the Age, 23 March 1981, page 2. (Question No. 8(9) (2) Is it a fact, as alleged in that article, that the Government has decided to charge import duty and sales tax on imported school work books. (3) If so, would this action confiict with the Florence Agreement. (4) What is the full title of the Florence Agreement, when was it signed and or ratified by Australia, and what is its purpose. rate of interest of 19.7 per cent (5) What is the Government's attitude towards the payment of import duty and sales tax on imported school work books. to be repaid had not been reduced (6) Has his Department, or any statutory authority under its control, made any investigation of the claim that import duty and sales tax will probably cause the cost of imported school work books to double; if so, is there any substance to this claim. (7) If an investigation has not been made, will he now cause it to take place. Mr MooreThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: (I) Yes. (2) No. Until recently work books, which are accepted as being combined exercise and text books, were generally classified under Item 48.18 of the Customs Tariff which is the item for exercise books and were dutiable at the rate of 25 per cent. The 25 per cent duty rate for exercise books was imposed on 28 September 1979 following the Government decision on the report by the Industries Assistance Commission on Paper Products dated 16 May 1979. an effective rate varying between Following a legal challenge and subsequent discussion it was agreed that the tariff classification of work books should be modified as follows: Work books designed essentially for writing in by users in which the printed text comprises a minor and clearly incidental aspect of the book will, as before, continue to fall to Tariff Item 48.18 and be dutiable at 25 per cent. Work books designed primarily to pose question and answer exercises with provision for answers therein will be classified under Tariff Item 49.01, which is the item for textbooks, and be entered free of duty. Work books comprising text material together with question and answer exercises will also continue to be entered under Tariff Item 49.01. In relation to the question of sales tax the following ruling currently applies: Books either imported or locally produced, which deal with educational subjects of a kind taught in non-profit schools or universities and which contain sets of questions or problems to be answered or worked out in spaces provided have been ruled exempt from sales tax under Item 51 (I) First Schedule, Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Act. (3) No. (4) The full title of the Florence Agreement is the UNESCO Agreement on the Importation of Educational Scientific and Cultural Materials. Its primary objective is to encourage the free flow of educational, scientific and cultural materials. Australia has not formally ratified the Florence Agreement; however it has in practice sought to give effect to the spirit of the Agreement's aims and objectives. (5} See 2 above. (6) No such investigation has been made. (7) No. The Government does not make changes in rates of duty on imported goods without first seeking advice from the Industries Assistance Commission. In this case the lAC submitted its report recommending a 25 per cent ad valorem duty, and the recommendation was accepted by the Government. In December 1976 a discussion paper based on the working party's report was tabled in Parliament for the purpose of seeking public comment on a possible natural disaster insurance scheme. Following a detailed assessment of this matrelease the report to the public; if ter, including comments received from the States, the insurance industry and other interested parties, the Government concluded that a natural disaster insurance scheme of the type outlined in the discussion paper would not be a cost-effective way of assisting in solutions to the problems identified and that a number of practical measures dealing more directly with the problems and involving less Government intervention would be more appropriate. Work on this matter is proceeding. Further background on the Government's decisions in this area is contained in my press release of 17 January 1979 and in a Policy Information Paper which I tabled in Parliament on 4 June 1979. Mr Campbell asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 29 April 1981 : (1) Has his attention been drawn to the recent occurrence of the disease encephalitis in the north of Western Australia. (2) How many cases of this disease have been identified in this area during the last 12 months. (3) How many of these cases were amongst Aboriginal people in this period. (4) What steps will the Government take in response to the occurrence of this disease. Mr MACKellar-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: (1 ) Yes. My Department has been in contact with Western Australia State Public Health Department concerning this outbreak. (2) There have been seven serologically confirmed clinical cases. (3) Five. I undertook to provide more detailed information to the honourable member. Speaker: Mr MALCOLM FRASER
Title: BUILDING INDUSTRY
text: The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: (1) Yes. The Government has also approved 37 Codes of Practice as recommendations to be read in suppnrt of the Code of General Principles. (2) The States have the conatitutional spect of occupational health and safety in private industry. Four State Governments have adopted the Code of General Principles with minor revisions in respect of their own employees. The Commonwealth has no detailed knowledge of the extent of adoption of the code by private industry. It is believed, however, that there is an increasing awareness both in the State Governments and private industry of the financial and humanitarian benefits to be gained from the implementation of properly structured and implemented occupational safety and health programs. (3) There has been no co-ordinated action to prepare translations of the Code of General Principles which is basically a management guide. At least 41 countries, represented for the most part by Head of State or Head of Government with accompanying delegations of Ministers and officials, are expected to attend. Over the last decade the practice has developed of holding the Meeting in different member countries of the Commonwealth. Recent Meetings have been held in Singapore, that those organisations will be Ottawa, Kingston, London and Lusaka. If smaller countries such as Singapore, Jamaica and Zambia can fulfil their obligations as Members of the Commonwealth of Nations, it is functions to be transferred. The right that Australia should, too. Much needs to be available in the way of facilities and equipment for a meeting of this level and size. Much of the equipment being provided, whether for example in the security area or for Conference Centre furnishings, will have a future government use. Decisions on the acquisition of equipment are made with future use in mind. There are currently 4 Second Division, 27 Third Division and 13 Fourth Division personnel partment on preparations for the forthcoming Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting. Some of these are seconded from other departments. Some additional staff will be taken on full time in preparation for the Meeting but the exact numbers will be determined as needs are identified. A number of officers have as required been employed part time on preparations of an administrative and policy kind for the Meeting. Their numbers have varied and will continue to do so in accordance with need. My Department's current estimate of expenditure on CHOGM is $12m. The greatest individual expenditure, about $6m, relates to security in Victoria. A substantial portion of this $6m will comprise transfer of funds from the Commonwealth to the State of Victoria to offset increased operating costs of the Victoria Police curity during CHOGM. Also included in the $6m for security is expenditure on security communications equipment such as portable radio transceivers ment. Much of this equipment will have a Commonwealth use after the Meeting. Other major items of expenditure include residential accommodation, transport, fitting out of the Meeting venue, furniture, and the operating costs of the Task Force which has been established to handle the arrangements for the Meeting. (2) As a general program of assistance for the development of transition education programs for young people, Transition Program funding is provided to the States following Commonwealth approval of broad State 'package' proposals for schools and TAFE institutions rather than for specific areas of disadvantage such as handicapped persons. Under the Program guidelines the Commonwealth seeks to encourage education authorities in the States to take account of the (Question No. 2275) needs of particular disadvantaged students, but it is for these authorities to determine priorities amongst individual proposals within the broad 'package' proposals approved by the Commonwealth. While it is not possible to identify all school projects specifically concerned with the handicapped, there have been a number of such projects funded and it is evident that the needs of the handicapped are being recognised by the responsible authorities. (3) In addition to Transition Program funding, it is possible for handicapped persons attending special schools and classes to benefit from an employment point of view through the Commonwealth's Special Education Program administered by the Commonwealth Schools Commission. This program aims to improve the quality and coverage of educational services for handicapped children by supplementing the funding of special schools and classes. While these funds are not specifically directed to assistance for the employment of handicapped persons, they may bc used for work experience and vocational training programs conducted by special schools and regular schools in which there are special classes. Within the Commonwealth's Special Education Program there is a Children in Residential Institutions element which funds projects designed to improve the educational prospects and to broaden the general experience of children living in institutions. It is possible for such projects to be concerned with transition, work experience and vocational training. it could borrow by the issue of As far as programs outside the education area are concerned, the Departments of Social Security and of Employment and Youth Affairs administer programs and services designed to assist the employment of handicapped persons. Subsidies under the Handicapped Persons Assistance Act and rehabilitation assistance through the Commonwealth Rehabilitation Service are administered by the Department of Social Security. Through the Department of Employment and Youth Affairs disabled persons registered for employment may receive assistance under the National Employment and Training System to gain the ment. Employment subsidies are provided for on-the-job training. A number of work preparation/training programs are funded and assistance for individuals to undertake formal training is available. Adult Secondary Assistance Scheme Mr Young asked the Minister for Education, upon notice, on 4 June 1981: Will he explain what is meant by the Government's announcement that eligibility for the Adult Secondary Assistance Scheme will be restricted to those needing qualifications for employment (Hansard, 30 April 1981,page 1843). Mr Fife-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: The Government's decision, following the Review of Commonwealth Functions, that eligibility under the Adult Secondary Education Assistance Scheme will be restricted to those needing qualifications for employment will mean that as from 1 January 1982, only applicants who have indicated an employment objective for which completion of matriculation level studies is considered to be essential or highly desirable will be eligible for consideration under the scheme. Acceptable employment objectives will include those requiring completion of a tertiary qualification for which matriculation is a pre-requisite. Mr Fife-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: (1) Yes, following the Review of Commonwealth Functions there has been some modification of the Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme (TEAS) eligibility rules which generally will take effect as from I January 1982. The general intention is also that students who have already qualified under the rules which have now been modified will continue to do so. Consequently, the decision, that participation in a de facto relationship will no longer qualify an applicant for independent status, wi1l not affect those students who have already qualified for independent status in this way. Those (Question No. 2439) granted independent status on this basis prior to 1982 will retain that status. (2) Yes, subject to their continuing to comply with the normal conditions of eligibility. (3) The decision that students will no longer be able to qualify for the living away-from-home rate if, being 21 years of age or more, they choose to live away from home will also take effect as from 1 January 1982. Students who have already qualified under the age 21 provision will continue to qualify on the same grounds after 1981 subject to their continuing to comply with other normal requirements. (4) Yes. (5) The provision whereby a sole parent, with a dependent child (or children) and who has independent status under TEAS, may be in receipt of $5,100 before the means test on personal income is applied is subject only to whether or not the child is wholly or substantially dependent on the applicant. It does not necessarily require that the applicant should be in receipt of supporting parent's benefit nor to have been involved in a de facto relationship. Students who have already qualified for this provision will continue to do so after 1981, new applicants as from I January 1982 wi\l be assessed against the ongoing requirements for independent status. (6) No. Students will continue to be eligible to apply for independent status if they have been employed full-time in the workforce for periods totalling five. However, one of the decisions following the Review of Commonwealth Functions was that periods of registration for employment which do not involve the receipt of unemployment benefits may now be taken into account in determining the two year qualifying period for independent status, provided the student was unemployed and in Australia and available for full-time work. Title: DIVISIONAL GROUP
text: the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 26 November 1980: What recommendations made since December 1977 by the Homeless Persons Advisory Committees (a) have been accepted, (b) have been rejected or (c) are still under consideration by the Government.

Speaker: Mr HUNT
Title: DIVISIONAL GROUP
text: The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question: Since 1977, the State Homeless Persons Advisory Committees, which have now been abolished, commented on a wide range of issues and on various Commonwealth Government programs. It is not appropriate to respond to the question in terms of recommendations accepted, rejected or under consideration, because: (i) in arate recommendations from the various State Committees, some of which have been provided by more than one State Committee, an unknown number of recommendations were made orally in discussions with the former Minister and officers of the Department; (ii) in the nature of Advisory Committees, the expression of views and discussion of issues is as important as (was) the submission of formal recommendations. Important issues raised by the Advisory Committees include: amendment of the Homeless Persons Assistance Act to broaden the range of services provided to homeless people; facilities and services to be provided to categories of homeless people other than the chronically homeless; an expansion and increase in recurrent subsidies provided under the Homeless Persons Assistance Act; and an expansion in the allocation of capital funds to the Homeless Persons Assistance Program. Mr Fife-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: (Question No 458) The Government has given its full support to the International Year of Disabled Persons. The situation with the Public Service Board and departments generally is as follows: (1) The Government and the Public Service Board have a policy of equal employment opportunity in the Australian Public Service. That policy is in keeping with the Government's endorsement of 'access to all aspects of community life' as one of the themes of IYDP. The policy of equal employment opportunity applies to disabled people seeking employment, or already employed, in the Australian Public Service. Disabled people employed in the Public Service receive the same rates of pay, have the same job classifications, have the same terms and conditions of employment and have the same promotion opportunities as their non-disabled peers in comparable jobs. 1981 marks the end of a decade of active involvement by the Public Service Board to ensure that disabled people have equality of opportunity in the Australian Public Service. The full list of steps taken by the Board is quite extensive. I will forward to the Honourable Member a resume of these initiatives, together with other material produced by the Public Service Board on the employment of disabled people in the Australian Public Service. As part of its commitment to the IYDP the Public Service Board is consolidating and extending its recruitment-based activities to ensure that people with disabilities continue to achieve. equal access to the Service. The Board has produced special recruitment literature and posters which aim to imform disabled people that they can apply for jobs in the Public Service and expect to get 'a fair go'. Special recruitment activities, using this new literature, have been planned for 1981. The Public Service will also continue to provide work therapy opportunities for up to 200 rehabilitees in 1981 under the Commonwealth Rehabilitation Service's work therapy scheme. The Board's activities to promote equal access to the Public Service and the recruitment of disabled people is an integral part of its equal employment opportunity program, a program which will continue well beyond 1981. The Public Service Board ployment not be viewed solely as a matter involving recruitment and placement of disabled people. Other important facets of equal employment opportunity, in which departments have an important role to play, include induction and orientation, access and job site modification, personnel development and training and rehabilitation of disabled staff. Permanent Heads of all departments have given the Board their full and active support for the implementation ofEEO for disabled staff in this and future years. To assist departments to focus on the needs of their disabled staff the Board is also conducting a series of seminars for senior managers on the employment of people with disabilities. The seminar series commenced in May and will continue on a monthly basis during 1981 and into early 1982. Departments have already taken steps to improve the employment position of their disabled staff. For example, the Department of Industrial Relations is consulting with its disabled employees concerning access, modification of amenities, training and career opportunities. It is also fostering a greater consciousness amongst its staff of the problems faced by disabled people, modifying amenities disabled employees and training stafr in the supervision of disabled employees. The Department of Employment and Youth Affairs, which is heavily involved in IYDP through the Government's programs for the employment of disabled people in the broader community has been expending considerable effort to modify the working environment, to obtain aids and provide induction, training and developmental programs for its disabled employees. In the Department of Defence a special video program has been produced showing disabled staff at work in the Department. The video promotes positive attitudes towards the employment of disabled people. The Department of Transport is also planning an education program to inform staff about the disabled, their rights as individuals and citizens and the causes and prevention of disablement. The Department of Housing and Construction, as part of its commitment to IYDP, has undertaken a survey of staff to determine the number of disabled people employed, the nature of the disability and the difficulties they face in the work environment. This survey indicated that 6.4 percent of its staff were disabled. The Department of Capital Territory is also undertaking a survey of its staff. 2(a) The Public Service Board, the employing authority in the Australian Public Service, has Special Placement Officers in each of its Regional Offices to assist in the recruitment and placement of disabled people. Special Placement Officers are able to arrange modified selection tests which take into account the applicant's disability e.g. for blind applicants tests can be administered in braille or on tape, for deaf applicants an interpreter can be provided. In 1980 the Special Placement Officers assisted 802 disabled applicants, of whom 251 were placed in employment. 20 percent of disabled applicants gained permanent jobs in the Public Service. This compares favourably with non-disabled applicants where only 15 percent were permanently appointed to comparable positions. Departments which took a substantial number of special placements during 1980 included Defence, Education, Employment and Youth Affairs, Home Affairs and Environment, Social Security and Veterans' Affairs, together with the Australian Bureau of Statistics and the Australian Taxation Office. All departments accept, wherever possible, disabled new entrants referred to them by the Special Placement Officers. The steps being taken by the Board to further increase the numbers of disabled people employed in the Public Service are detailed in (1) above. is concerned that equality of em2(b) There is a long-standing policy of ensuring that public buildings constructed by the Commonwealth permit reasonable access by disabled people and comply with the Australian Standards relating to Design Rules for Access by the Disabled. Access for disabled people has been provided in such buildings as the Family jChildren's Court building and the Public Service Board's MCLachlan Offices in Canberra. The Australian Defence Force Academy will include in certain areas special facilities for the disabled. The provision of facilities for disabled people is included in the refurbishment program for the Administrative Building, occupied by the Departments of Foreign Affairs and Attorney-General's. In its capacity as the central property authority, the Department of Administrative Services, in conjunction with the Department of Housing and Construction, is implementing a strategy for access modifications to Commonwealth-owned buildings. This involves a survey of over 500 buildings to identify any necessary modification work. Details on the Government's activities were provided by my colleague Mr MCVeigh in answer to question 483 on 26 March 1981 (Hansard Page 1062). to reduce difficulties for (3) Departmental IYDP programs are being funded within their overall 1980-81 budget allocations. Mr Fife-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: The purpose of the Student Organisations (Amenities and Services) Statute is to prescribe the amenities and services on which fees monies compulsorily collected from all students may be spent. Where the Council of the University makes compulsory fees monies available to a student organisation for (Question No. 774) the provision by that organisation of amenities or services, then it is the duty of the Council to ensure that the monies are applied only in respect of amenities and services that are not of an academic nature, that are of direct benefit to the University, and that have been declared in a University statute to be the Ausamenities or services in respect of that organisation. The current provisions of the Australian National University Act enable the University to charge lower fees to students who indicate their wish not to join particular student associations, but do not require the University to do so. It has been the Government's wish for the University to act to see that students who join a particular student organisation pay a separate membership fee, the proceeds of which are to be directed towards supporting voluntary activities which are not eligible for support from the proceeds of the compulsory fee for amenities and services payable by all students. Such an arrangement would present a clear distinction between the students who choose to join an organisation and those who do not. The Government, after reviewing the operation of the 1979 amendments at the Australian National University during 1980, decided to introduce further amending legislation which has now passed both Houses of Parliament. The purpose of this legislation is threefold. First, it makes income derived from the application of compulsory student fees moneys subject to the same conditions as the fees themselves. Second, where both compulsory fees moneys and other moneys are applied with the effect of producing income, that income must be apportioned according to the applications. Third, the administrative expenses of student organisations must also be apportioned, so that only activities student amenities and services can be a charge on compulsory fees moneys. With the enactment of this legislation, the Government is confident that be used by student organisations funding of socio.political activities. text: The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question: (l) About ten representations responsibility have been received. (2) Some additional clerical staff have been allocated where necessary to ensure that undue delays do not occur. (3) It is estimated that an additional 7,600 claims for supporting parent's benefit were received in Queensland during the period to 8 May 1981, and that some 6,800 sole parents were granted supporting parent's benefit during the same period solely as a result of the reduction in 'waiting period' for supporting parent's benefit as known what proportion of these people would have previously been eligible for Family Assistance Payments. (5) No provisions have been made for immediate cash payments of benefits; however it is extremely rare that complaints Table 3 are received regarding difficulties in cashing cheques. Mr Killen-The answe- t9 the honourable member's question is as follows: (1) The Department does not keep records on whether an individual officer or employee has been on strike or engaged in any restrictive work actions. However, it is possible to identify several groups of employees who have engaged in such activities during each of the last two years. These groups include employees' at Williamstown and Garden' Island. Dockyards, foremen, storemen and packers, and a substantial number of Communications officers in the Clerical grades. It is th-refore possible to esti(Question No. 1339) mate the number of officers or employees who have been on strike or who have engaged in restrictive work action at 'approximately 6500. . , (2) During the year ende(l 31 March 1980, 182,605 manhours were lost through strikes. DurIng the year ended 31 March 1981, 474,459 manhours wete lost through strikes. Of the latter figure 222,092 manhours were lost in one dispute, concerning the manning of the Plate Preservation Line at Williamstown Dockyard. Because of the nature of restrictive work actions it has not been possible to ascertain the number of manhours involved in them. (3) No officers or employees have been paid for any periods during which they have been on strike. (4) Most employees whose conditions of employment are governed by Public Service Arbitrator's Determination No. 44 of 1955 normally receive a naval work adjustment allowance. This allowance currentlly rariges between $3.60 and $9.40 per week. When these employees, most of whom are employed at Williamstown and Garden Island Dockyards, engage in any restrictive work practices this allowance is not paid. Universities and Colleges of Advanced Education: Total Enrolments Mr Rocher asked the Minister for Education, upon notice, on 29 April 1981 : (1) What progress has been made in pursuing the recommendations contained in the report of the Committee of Review into the Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme (the Williams Committee) that universities and colleges of advanced education should strive for more accuracy in recording the number of their total enrolments. (2) Are the numbers of effective full-time students institutions being satisfactorily recorded and is the Government satisfied that the numbers are accurate. Mr Fife-The reply to the honourable member's question is as follows: The Committee of Inquiry into Education and Training established in 1976 under the chairmanship of Professor Sir Bruce Williams recommended, R6.25,' . . . a considerable improvement in the accuracy and comprehensiveness of advanced education statistics to make possible comparative studies that should guide any further decisions on rationalisation.' This was one of a number of Williams Committee recommendations referred to the Tertiary Education Commission for consideration. At present different measures are used to calculate the number of equivalent full time students, 'student load', university and advanced education sectors. For universities student load is measured in terms of the weighted student unit (WSU) which is calculated by measuring the academic program for each student against the normal program for a full time student in each course. Higher degree enrolments are given special weightings. For colleges of advanced education student load is calculated by giving a weight of 1.0 to full time students and 0.5 to part time and external students. There are difficulties in accurately calculating student load in colleges of advanced education because the measures currently being used tend to overstate it. The Tertiary Education Commission, in Volume 1 Part 1 of its Report for the 1982-84 Triennium, has advised that it considers that since most part time students in advanced education, and particularly external students, undertake less than one-half of a full year's work, the real student load generated by a part time enrolment is likely to be closer to 0.4 than 0.5 of the load of a full time student. The Commission has taken this into consideration in formulating its recommendations on the advanced education sector. The development of a WSU type measure is under consideration by the Joint Committee on Advanced Education Statistics. Speaker: Mr HOWARD
Title: NAVAL ACTIVITY IN THE INDIAN OCEAN
text: The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: (1') The Enemy Subjects Trust Account was established on 6 October 1939 in accordance with the provisions of section 14 of the Trading with the Enemy Act 1939 to receive and deal with the proceeds of disposal of property formerly owned by Enemy Subjects. (2), (3) and (4) Funds which became available earlier have been distributed over the years, including two general distributions to eligible ex-prisoners of war and their dependants. Since no transactions involving receipts to the Account have occurred for several years and since it seems most unlikely that any further claims on the Account will arise, it has been decided that its continuation is no longer justified. Defence Force Review Tribunal: Report on Salaries and Conditions Mr Scholes asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 14 May 1981: (1) Has the report by the Defence Force Review Tribunal on Salaries and Conditions of Members of the Defence Forces been completed. . (2) If not, has the time taken for the review been excessive and will he seek to have the finalisation of the Report expedited. (3) Has an amount of $103m been deducted from the appropriation for the Defence Forces accounts savings, as a result of the Report not being available when initally anticipated. (4) Will he ensure that the operative date of any beneficial changes to service conditions and salaries will be backdated, in order that Service personnel taged by delays in the preparation or approval of the Tribunal's recommendations. Mr Killen-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: (1) No. (2) I do not consider the time taken for the review to cessive. The Committee of Reference for Defence Force Pay was given its terms of reference on 22 July 1980. The Committee submitted to me an interim report on 31 October 1980 on the work value aspect of the reference recommending an increase in Service remuneration on grounds of work value change. This recommendation has been approved and implemented. Additionally, in December 1980, the Committee of Reference was tasked with an examination of appropriate allowances for Special Action Forces. The report on this subject (Question No. 2285) was presented on 6 March 1981. Without doubt, this intervening but extreinely urgent reference eelayed to some extent continuance of the work required by the earlier reference. Despite these strictures on the time of the Committee, two members of which are full-time members of the Arbitration Commission a further report is expected to be forthcoming by about the end ofJuly 1981. (3) The amount of$103m (initially $11 Om) was included in the Defence Budget estimates for 1980-81 by Department of Finance, as an Allowance to meet prospective increases in wage and salary rates of both Service and civilian personnel within Defence. The actual additional estimate for the salaries sought by Defence for 1980-81 is $91.795m to cover mainly increases flowing from national wage case decisions and work value increases so far awarded to both Service personnel and civilians. (4) The interim increase recommended by the Committee of Reference, which is mentioned in 2. above, was effective from 22 July 1980. This was the date terms of reference for the inquiry were given to the Committee of Reference. In the report accompanying the recommendations, the Committee of Reference stated that it should not be inferred that 22 July 1980 will be the operative date for the final work value assessment or for other recommendations made necessary by the terms of reference. That final date of effect is to be a matter for separate consideration. balance of funds that remained in Australian Army Reserves (Question No. 2295) Mr Scholes asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 14 May 1981: (1) Did the 1980-81 Budget estimates indicate the (Question No. 2294) estimated strength of the Australian Army Reserves to be 31,550. (4) What is the current estimate of the numbers of members of the Army Reserve for June 1981. Mr Killen-The answers to the honourable member's questions are as follows: will not be financially disadvan(1) Yes. (2) The supplementary estimates in Appropriation Bill (No.3) 1980-81 comprehend a reduced estimated target for 30 June 1981 of 31260 but latest returns indicate now that this target will not be reached. (3) Army has made no policy changes in the method of be exassessing numbers since the expansion began. Headquarters Field Force was made aware last February of one Army Reserve Officer, who on his own initiative encouraged his subordinates to delay the declaration of non-effective members. Orders were immediately given to prevent such a practice being contemplated elsewhere. Mr Jacobi asked the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs, upon notice, on 14 May 1981: (1) Has his attention been release of the recent Prices Justification Tribunal (PJT) re port on petrol prices, the extent of discounting petrol has increased markedly in New South Wales, Victoria and Queensland. (2) Is it a fact that South shared in the benefits of the resultant lower level of pertrol prices. (3) Is he satisfied that petrol resellers and motorists in South Australia are not being discriminated against by the oil companies; if not, will he (a) PJT to investigate immediately this discrimination by the oil companies in South Australia and (b) continue to monitor petrol pricing throughout Australia. Mr Moore-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: (I ) No. Indeed I have noted reports that some oil companies intended to withdraw discounts, following the re lease of the PJT report of 31 March 1981 on petroleum prod uct prices. I am not able to confirm or deny the accuracy of those reports nor to say whether market conditions will enable companies to withdraw those discounts. {2) See answer to (I) above. (3) According to ABS figures (catalogue No. 6403.0) the average retail price of super grade petrol in Adelaide during the March quarter of 1981 was higher than in other State capi tals. In the previous quarter the reverse applied. (4) Prices determined by the PJT for the oil companies are maximum justified prices. They differ between States only to the extent of differences in State taxes or other charges levied on petroleum products. (Question No. 2296) Oil companies are not obliged to charge the maximum jus tified prices and, where competition is keen, they might not be able to obtain the full justified price. Actual prices to resellers would reflect both the strength of competition of any State Defence Science and Technology price controls that may apply. The Petroleum Products Pricing Authority will take over from the PJT the respnmsibility for monitoring prices charged by the oil companies. It will have powers as proposed in the Petroleum Products Pricing Bill which I introduced into Par liament on 27 May 1981. As the Commonwealth's jurisdiction over prices is limited to the corporate sector, effective action to monitor retail pet rol prices, including the margins applied by non-corporate resellers, is a matter for State Governments to consider. given on his authorisation. (2) If the alliance leads to a re-arming of Japan, what impli cations will this have for Australia and what would be the effect on Australian foreign affairs and defence policy. (3) Did the United States Government consult with the Australian Government before announcing this alliance. (4) Has the USA any obligation, either legal or moral, to consult with Australia on such a matter. (5) If the Australian Government was consulted, what response did it give. (6) If the Australian Government was not consulted on this matter, (a) is this a cause of concern for the Australian Government and (b) what guarantee is there that the USA will consult Australia on any future foreign policy initiative involving countries in the area. Mr Street-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: (I) An alliance between tIot been announced recently. by Prime Minister Zenko Suzuki and President Ronald Reagan on 8 May, it was stated that 'the Prime Minister and the President, recognising that the alliance between Japan and the United States is built upon their shared values of democracy and liberty, reaffirmed their solidarity, friendship and mutual trust'. Although there has been debate in Japan about the interpretation of the word 'alliance' in this sentence, in particular as to whether it committed Japan to a new or altered security relationship with the United States, the Government of Japan has made it clear that its relationship with the United States remains as it has been. (2) The joint communique further states that 'the Prime Minister and the President reaffirmed their belief that the Japan-United States Treaty of Mutual Cooperation and Security is the foundation of peace and stability in the Far East and the defense of Japan. In insuring peace and stability in region and the defense of Japan, they acknowledged the desirability of an appropriate division of roles between Japan and the United States. The Prime Minister stated that Japan, on its own initiative and in accordance with its constitution and basic defense policy, will seek to make even greater efforts for improving its defense capabilities in Japanese territories and in its surrounding sea and air space, and for further alleviating the financial burden of US forces in Japan. The President expressed his understanding of the statement by the Prime Minister.' These positions outlined in the communique do 'not alter our perception of Japan's defence and security policies nor of Japan's relations with the United States. The Government sees cooperation under the Japan-United States Treaty of Mutual Cooperation and Security as a vital part of the defence of the Asia/Pacific region, as are the separate arrangements under ANZUS. It is in Australia's interest that the defence relationship between Japan and the United States remain a harmonious one. (3), (4), (5) and (6) As suggested in answer to questions (1) and (2), no event as suggested by those questions took place which required specific consultations with Australia by any other government. In both formal and informal consultations with the United States on security issues in the Pacific area, discussion would include, as appropriate from time to time, subjects related to Japan. of consultations with Japan on matters of common international concern include subjects such as Japan's, and our own, relations with the United States. Replacement ofHMAS 'Melbourne' Mr Fry asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 27 May 1981: (1) What proportion of the annual Defence budget is spent on the acquisition of new equipment. (2) What are the implications for the Army and Air Force, in terms of new equipment, from the decision to replace HMAS Melbourne with another aircraft carrier or carriers. (3) For how many years will the proportion of the Defence budget allocated for purchase of capital equipment be tied up in paying off a new aircraft carrier. (4) Does he favour an aircraft carrier rather than a mix of conventional submarines and small surface ships for the protection of Australia; if so, why. (5) Is HMAS Melbourne being replaced by another aircraft carrier so as to enable Australia to project a visible presence in the South Pacific and Indian Oceans. (6) Will other powers in the area interpret the replacement ofHMAS Melbourne in the terms referred to in part (5). the United States and Japan has In the joint communique issued (7) Is the career structure of the Royal Australian Navy centred around serving on an aircraft carrier. (8) Has Australian thinking on a replacement for HMAS Melbourne been influenced by United States of America Naval doctrine. (9) How many Oberon-class submarines could be purchased from the sum necessary to replace HMAS Melbourne with another aircraft carrier. Mr Killen-The answers to the honourable member's questions are as follows: (I) The proportions of total Defence expenditures spent on capital equipment over the financial years 1975-76 to 1979-80 are 8.3 per cent, 12.8 per cent, 13.2 per cent, 15.5 per cent and 16.4 per cent respectively. On 19 February 1980 the Prime Minister announced in Parliament details of a defence the program which is expected to raise the proportion of expenditure on capital investment to over 25 per cent of the defence vote by 1984-85. (2) The acquisition of new major capital equipment is considered primarily in the context of its contribution to the development of defence force capabilities as a whole. Planning for the development of Army and Air Force capabilities will necessarily take account of concurrent development of the RAN. (3) None. In anyone year the major equipment component of the Defence Budget comprises financial allocations for a range of equipment approved in earlier years and for new equipment to be approved in the Budget year. (4) Studies to assisnhe selection of an aircraft carrier design are continuing. Conventional submarines and small surface ships are not alternatives to the anti-submarines helicopters which will be deployed with any new carrier. The carrier is to have potential for operating short take-off and vertical landing (STOVL) aircraft. The Government will consider in 1983 whether or not to acquire STOVL aircraft, in the light of aircraft costs, capabilities and other relevant factors. (5) See my answer (4) above. A new carrier would, as do HMAS Melbourne and other major ships of the RAN,conduct operations in the Pacific and Indian Oceans. (6) I cannot comment accurately on how neighbouring Similarly, established patterns states might interpret Government decisions on Australian defence force development. I should expect them to see a decision to acquire a helicopter carrier as a military matter rather than, as the question implies, a political one. (7) No. Service with the aircraft carrier is not a prerequisite for advancement in the RAN. (Question No. 2331) (8) No. Decisions on Australian defence force development are based on Government assessments of Australian defence needs. (9) See my answer to (4) above. No useful answer can be given to this question. The eventual cost of a new carrier will depend on the type of ship selected and the range of capabilities that it might include. The Oberon submarine is no longer in production.
